Wearing a face mask remains mandatory for everyone in the following areas:    - on public transport from entering the indoor areas of the airport, the station, on the platform or a bus, (pre-)metro, tram, train stop or any other means of transport organised by a public authority. Public transport operators and all bus operators carrying out public transport services are not required to cover their nose and mouth, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in the indoor areas of organised collective transport (i.e. transport organised in advance with a clear itinerary or final destination and a vehicle with at least 9+1 seats (passengers + driver)), this does not apply to public transport operators, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  - in establishments and places where close-contact professions are carried out. This applies to service providers and customers where there is direct physical contact between the service provider and the customer or where the distance of 1.5 metres cannot be guaranteed between the service provider and the customer for a duration of at least 15 minutes;  - the publicly accessible areas of companies, associations and services;  the publicly accessible areas of commercial establishments, shops and shopping centres;  libraries, game and multimedia libraries;  - in the indoor areas accessible to the public of establishments belonging to the sports sector, including fitness centres and establishments that may remain open in accordance with Article 7, Â§1 of the Royal Decree, subject to items 11 and 12 below;  - in places of worship and buildings intended for the public practice of non-denominational moral services;  when moving around in public and non-public parts of courthouses and courtrooms and, in other cases, in accordance with the guidelines laid down by the Chairman;  - the publicly accessible areas of government buildings;  establishments and places where catering activities are permitted, both for staff and those customers who are not seated at a table or at the bar;  locations where authorised private gatherings and activities in an organised context take place with more than 50 people indoors or 100 people outdoors;  - venues for events of any size, including mass events, authorised outdoor conferences and authorised sports competitions;  trade fairs, including exhibitions;  - other locations where access is organised in accordance with the Cooperation Agreement of 14 July 2021 with regard to the CST. *the indoor areas of schools and educational institutions;  - the indoor areas of the after-school care facilities for primary school children.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220127105912/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/

Schools and universities in the country are attending in-person classes. Face-to-face classes are allowed when providing a physical distance of at least 1.5 m, wearing protective face masks, hygiene on the hands, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314214227/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Employers and recruitment bodies to organize the work process of employees in remote form (distance work / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of at most 50% of the staff.  Employers and appointment bodies in all administrations within the meaning of Art. 1 of the Administration Act organize the work process of the employees, as:  (a) establish working hours with variable limits and the start of the working day between 7.30 am and 10.00 am, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work;  (b) assign remote work to at least 50% of staff, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work.  Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centers, dialysis centers, hospices and nursing homes organize the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order. The employer can arrange for a COVID-19 study to be performed with rapid on-site antigen testing. A protocol shall be drawn up for the conducted examination, in which the names of the employee, the result of the test and the date of its performance shall be entered. The protocol is signed by the employer and the respondents. The results are valid up to 48 hours after sampling.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314214227/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

The holding of congress-conference events, seminars, symposiums, trainings, competitions, exams and other group events of this nature is suspended. The holding of all mass events, such as music and other festivals, fairs, folklore initiatives and others of such nature, shall be suspended.  Visits to libraries, museums, galleries, cinemas, theaters, circus performances, concerts and other indoor performances are suspended. Indoor team sports are suspended, with the exception of trainings and competitions for registered athletes at licensed sports federations. Sports competitions are allowed without an audience.  Visits to fitness centers, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centers, SPA centers, wellness centers and thalassotherapy centers are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation.  Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping center type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centers.  Exceptions to the above apply if all staff have proof of vaccination, COVID illness or a negative COVID test.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314214227/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Holdings of a private nature (baptisms, weddings, etc.) are allowed with the participation of no more than 15 people indoors and 30 people outdoors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314214227/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Public transport is operating. All persons must cover their mouth and nose with a mask or covering on all public transportation including while in railway, bus and metro stations, and airports etc.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No curfew is in place. http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No restrictions on interstate or intercity travel. http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travellers from a green or orange zone country can enter Bulgaria without quarantine provided they present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19, has received a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or antigen COVID test result conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country, or has recovered from COVID-19. Similar documents which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, such as a U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Vaccination Record Card, are also accepted.  Travellers from a red zone country can enter Bulgaria without quarantine if they present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19, has received a negative COVID test result, or has recovered from COVID-19. Similar documents which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, such as a CDC Vaccination Record Card, are also accepted.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

PCR testing is widely available at sites across the country, including hospitals and private laboratories. Currently 100 hospitals and laboratories in Bulgaria are officially accredited by the Ministry of Health.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Any person who has made contact within 48 hours before and up to 14 days after the onset of symptoms in a patient should be considered when determining close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19. If the confirmed case is asymptomatic, contact is any person who has been in contact with the case within 48 hours before up to 14 days after taking the sample that led to the laboratory confirmation.   All close contacts of a confirmed case of COVID-19, at the discretion of an epidemiologist from RHI, are quarantined at home or elsewhere for accommodation and medical supervision for 7 -day period, as of the last contact with the sick person. The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is carried out by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspectorate.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314221945/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse

All persons must wear a mask that covers their mouth and nose in all indoor public spaces as well as in open public spaces where there is a crowd of people and it is not possible to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m. Scarves or substitute face coverings are no longer allowed in place of a mask  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

General vaccination has started for Bulgarian nationals, long-term and permanent residents; however, availability is fluid and based on supply.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314213936/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No additional measures for the elderly found.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220314214227/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

No change in policy.    Employers should take the following measures:  Ensure that all surfaces in your workplace are clean and hygienically correct. Use alcohol-based disinfectants (minimum 70%).  Clean contact points in buildings at least three times a day, such as door handles, window handles, faucets in toilets and kitchens, cistern buttons, remote controls, power switches, door bells, elevator buttons, reception desks and more touch surfaces used by a large number of people.  Touching contaminated surfaces by employees and clients is one of the main ways the COVID-19 virus spreads.  Clean all touch surfaces at least twice a day: desktops, smartphones and other phones, laptops, keyboards, and computers according to user instructions.  Meeting rooms, trainings and other areas where a large number of people gather should be cleaned after each meeting.  Place hand sanitizers in visible places everywhere in the work environment, especially in public places where people have fewer opportunities to wash their hands regularly. Ensure that these funds are regularly updated.  For hand washing in toilets, provide warm running water and soap, as well as disposable paper towels.  Install waste bins with lids to safely dispose of used paper towels and other waste in toilets and other rooms.  Place the instructions on proper hand washing in a visible place in the toilet.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228131602/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/preporuke

No policy change.  Exceptionally, the new Order allows the organization of larger gatherings indoors and outdoors, provided that the size of the space allows the implementation of hygienic and epidemiological measures, but not more than 60 people indoors or 200 people outdoors, provided that all participants together have a negative antigen test (not older than 24 hours) or a PCR test (not older than 48 hours) or a certificate of overcoming COVID-19 (not older than 4 months) or a certificate of completed vaccination (not older than 6 months after receiving the second vaccine doses, ie 9 months after receiving the third vaccine dose).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228133317/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

Provision of services in catering facilities takes place with a distance of at least 2 meters between tables, and catering facilities that organize live music, disco clubs, as well as facilities for similar purposes must implement VPT (vaccinated, ill, tested, rule) with the obligatory observance of a distance of at least 2 meters between the tables.    In the part of the Order for sports competitions, it is allowed to hold outdoor sports competitions in the presence of spectators, in compliance with general hygienic and epidemiological measures, and indoors in the presence of spectators, subject to the application of VPT rules (vaccinated, ) and a distance between spectators of at least 2 meters.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228132129/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/867/na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-staba-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva

No policy change.  It is allowed to gather people in a certain area under the following conditions:  no more than 30 people indoors;  no more than 100 people in the open.  All gatherings within the stated limits must take place in a space that allows a mandatory physical distance of at least 2 meters between persons (except members of the same household).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228133317/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

Hygienic and epidemiological measures must be observed at all indoor gatherings, and a physical distance of at least two meters must be maintained, and all participants in gatherings that bring together more than 300 people indoors must have:      â¢ negative antigen test, not older than 24 hours or PCR test, not older than 48 hours, or      â¢ a certificate of illness of COVID-19, not older than 4 months, or      â¢ confirmation of completed vaccination (not older than 4 months after the second dose of vaccine, or 12 months after the third dose of vaccine);    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228132129/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/867/na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-staba-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva

No policy change.  It is mandatory to wear a mask in the open if a distance of 2 meters cannot be achieved. It is mandatory to wear masks at public transport stops, markets / open markets and other places where there is a greater fluctuation of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228133317/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

The new Order , which is in force since February 24, 2022. year, it is still mandatory to wear a mask indoors (with a distance of at least 2 meters) in all health care institutions, institutions that care for the elderly, institutions that care for and accommodate people with disabilities and people with mental disorders, criminal correctional and other social protection institutions, as well as means of public transport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228132129/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/867/na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-staba-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva

No policy change.    A foreigner who meets conditions for entry to BiH prescribed by Law on Aliens, may enter BiH if he/she at the BiH Border Crossing Points presents any of the following:    negative PCR test or rapid antigen test on SARS-CoV-2, not older than 48 hours if he/she comes from an European country, and if he/she comes from another country, not older than 72 hours until arrival at the border crossing point ofBosnia and Herzegovina,    certificate that a person has received the second dose of vaccine for COVID-19 before more than 14 days before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH or has received one dose before 14 days and more before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH, if it is a single dose vaccine,    certificate issued by doctor showing that he/she has recovered from COVID-19 in the previous period from 14 to 180 days until the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205125253/http://www.granpol.gov.ba/Content/Read/76?title=Stranci&lang=en

No change in policy.    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228142523/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools  Compulsory schools and upper secondary schools (e.g. baccalaureate and vocational schools), federal high school and vocational college final exams and continuing education: Masks must be worn in indoor areas of upper secondary schools. All other measures for compulsory schools and upper secondary schools are the responsibility of the cantons.    Tertiary level (e.g. universities, universities of applied sciences and colleges of higher education) and continuing education: Access to certain educational offerings and exams in this area is limited to people who are vaccinated or recovered or have a certificate for a negative test result (3G). Masks must be worn. You will find further details in the explanatory notes to Art. 19a of the Ordinance on Measures during the Special Situation to combat the COVID-19 Epidemic.    Recreational courses: The rules for events apply, i.e. basically the mask and certificate requirement (vaccinated or recovered, 2G) in indoor areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207162650/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

But the following recommendation also applies: wear a mask in any situation where you want to protect yourself and others. The mask should always cover your nose and mouth.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220311100556/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/masken.html#-655746524

Work  Recommendation to work from home: Working from home is recommended in all areas where it is possible to work from home without disproportionate effort.    COVID certificate: Employers may check whether their employees are vaccinated or recovered or have a certificate for a negative test result (3G) if this is necessary for deciding on appropriate precautionary measures or for implementing testing concepts. The information on immunity status or the test result may not be used for any other purpose. Employees must be consulted on the use of the certificate and the measures derived from this, and these must be documented in writing. On data protection grounds, employers must use the âlight certificateâ with minimised data wherever possible.    Masks compulsory indoors: Masks are compulsory for all employees in indoor areas where several people are present. Exceptions apply in situations where a mask cannot be worn for safety reasons or owing to the nature of the activity as well as to people who cannot wear a mask for medical reasons. In particular, there is no exception to the mask-wearing requirement if it is an establishment in which employees meet the 2G+ requirements (vaccinated/recovered within last 4 months or vaccinated/recovered with negative test).    Protection in the workplace: Information can be found (in German, French and Italian) on the page Precautionary measures and on the page People at especially high risk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207162650/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Masks required in healthcare settings    Protecting workers: requirements  Employers are not required to draw up and implement precautionary measures provided their businesses are not accessible to the public. However, they are required to ensure their employees are protected in accordance with the ordinance. This means employers must ensure that their employees can comply with the hygiene and distancing recommendations and the mask-wearing requirement indoors.    Employers must make sure that their employees can meet their work obligations from home wherever the type of work allows and it is possible for them to do so with proportionate effort. Employers must take appropriate organisational and technical measures.     Employers must also introduce further measures applying the STOP principle (Substitution, Technical measures, Organisational measures, Personal protective equipment). These include, for example, physical separation, separate teams or regular airing/ventilation. Employers now have the option of requesting that employees show a COVID certificate and of using this information to ensure adequate protection.    https://archive.fo/EiouI  https://archive.fo/rjt1j

11/3/22    Chapter 4a90 Measures to protect Employees at High Risk  90 Inserted by No I of the O of 13 Jan. 2021 (Employees at High Risk) (AS 2021 5). Amended by No I of the O of 17 Dec. 2021, in force from 1 Jan. 2022 until 31 March 2022 (AS 2021 881; Art. 29 para. 7).    Art. 27a  1 Employers shall enable their employees at high risk to carry out their working duties from home. They shall take the appropriate organisational and technical measures to achieve this.91    2 Where it is not possible for employees to carry out their regular working duties from home, employers shall, in derogation from the contract of employment and for the same pay, assign the employees concerned equivalent alternative work that can be performed from home.    3 Where for operational reasons the presence of employees at high risk in the workplace is essential at all or at certain times, they may carry out their regular activities in the workplace provided the following requirements are met:    a.  The workplace is organised so as to prevent any close contact with other persons, in particular by providing the employee concerned with his or her own room or a clearly separate working area.  b.  In cases where close contact cannot be avoided at all times, appropriate protective measures shall be taken in accordance with the STOP principle (substitution, technical measures, organisational measures, personal protective equipment).  4 If it is not possible for the employees concerned to work in accordance with paragraphs 1â3, the employer shall in derogation from the contract of employment assign them equivalent alternative work in their normal workplace for the same pay in conditions which meet the requirements of paragraph 3 letters a and b.    5 Before the employer takes any measures, he or she shall consult the employees concerned. The employer shall record the measures decided in writing and notify the employees of the same in a suitable manner.    6 The employee concerned may decline to carry out work assigned to him or her if the employer fails to meet the requirements of paragraphs 1â4 or if the employee regards his or her personal risk of infection with the coronavirus for specific reasons as being too high despite the employer taking measures in accordance with paragraphs 3 and 4. The employer may request a medical certificate.    7 If it is not possible for the employee concerned to work in accordance with paragraphs 1â4, or if the employee declines the work assigned in terms of paragraph 6, the employer shall furlough the employee while continuing to pay his or her salary.    8 Employees shall give notice that they are at high risk by making a personal declaration. The employer may request a medical certificate.    9 Article 2 paragraph 3quater of the COVID-19 Loss of Earnings Ordinance of 20 March 202092 governs claims for compensation for loss of earnings related to the corona pandemic.    10 The following persons are regarded as being at high risk:    a.  pregnant women;  b.  persons with the diseases or genetic anomalies listed in Annex 7 who cannot be vaccinated on medical grounds.  11 The following persons are not regarded as being at high risk:    a.  pregnant women who have been vaccinated against COVID-19, for 270 days from the date on which the vaccination is administered in full;  b.  persons specified in paragraph 10 who have been infected with Sars-CoV-2 and have recovered:1.  when based on a molecular-biological analysis for Sars-CoV-2: for 270 days from the eleventh day after confirmation of infection,  2.93  when based on an analysis for Sars-CoV-2 antibodies: for the period of validity of the related certificate (Art. 34a para. 1 let. c of the COVID-19 Ordinance on Certificates of 4 June 202194).95  12 The diseases and genetic anomalies referred to in paragraph 10 are defined in Annex 7 on the basis of medical criteria. The list of these criteria is not exhaustive. A clinical assessment of the risk in specific cases remains reserved and may lead to persons being classed as being at high risk under paragraph 10bis.    13 The FDHA shall continually update Annex 7 based on the state of science.    14 â¦96    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.fedlex.admin.ch/eli/cc/2020/438/en

Events  Indoors    Access to indoor events for people aged 16 and over is basically restricted to people who are vaccinated or recovered (2G).    Exempt from this COVID certificate requirement are:    Religious ceremonies, funerals, events that fall within the scope of the normal activities and services of public authorities, political events and self-help groups with up to 50 people. For these indoor events, masks must be worn, the consumption of food and drinks is banned.  Blood donation campaigns are not considered events and are therefore not subject to the COVID certificate requirement. The current precautionary measures continue to apply to these campaigns.  Basically masks must be worn for all events indoors. Where neither wearing masks nor compulsory seating is possible, only vaccinated or recovered people who can present a certificate for a negative test result (2G+) are admitted.    You will find more detailed information on the various areas of application of the COVID certificate and the exceptions on the Use of the COVID certificate page.    Outdoors    At outdoor events, access for people aged 16 and over is also restricted to people who are vaccinated or recovered (2G). The organiser can voluntarily limit access to vaccinated or recovered people who also have a certificate for a negative test result (2G+).Access restrictions can be waived if not more than 300 people are admitted and guests do not dance. Precise details may be found on the Precautionary measures page.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207162650/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

17/2/22    From 17 February: Almost all measures lifted  From Thursday, 17 February, the following protective measures will be lifted throughout Switzerland:  - mask requirement in shops, restaurants, as well as in other public settings (facilities, venues and events)  - mask requirement in the workplace  - access restrictions regulated by COVID certificate (3G, 2G and 2G+-rule) to facilities and venues such as cinemas, theatres and restaurants, as well as events  - permit requirement for large-scale events  - restrictions on private gatherings    In agreement with the Federal Council, voluntary capacity restrictions in the retail sector and in cablecars and gondolas will be lifted.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.admin.ch/gov/en/start/documentation/media-releases/media-releases-federal-council.msg-id-87216.html

Who is not permitted to enter Switzerland?  Foreign nationals without proof of a recognised vaccination (see question Â«How can I prove that I am vaccinated?Â») seeking to travel to Switzerland from a SEM high-risk country for a stay here of up to three months without a visa and who do not meet any of the requirements under Â«Who is permitted to enter Switzerland?Â» are not permitted to enter Switzerland. These persons include:    Persons who wish to obtain services in Switzerland;  Tourists, visitors and participants in events;  Persons who wish to come to Switzerland for medical treatment that has not yet begun or that is not regarded as urgently required;  Persons seeking employment or who have been invited for a job interview in Switzerland;  Persons who wish to submit an application for a residence permit.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220220164905/https://www.sem.admin.ch/sem/en/home/sem/aktuell/faq-einreiseverweigerung.html#-1871257744

21/2/22  All employees have protection under the short-time working scheme.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130074141/https://www.arbeit.swiss/secoalv/en/home/menue/unternehmen/versicherungsleistungen/kurzarbeit-covid-19.html

Loss of earnings payments to continue for certain groups of people  Once measures are lifted, there will no longer be a need for most economic support measures. Therefore, claims for loss of earnings as a result of business closures, event bans, reduced working hours and a shortfall in outside care will no longer be possible from 17 February.      An exception applies until 30 June for persons working in the events sector whose employment is significantly restricted due to measures to combat the COVID-19 epidemic. An exception also applies until the end of March for persons who have to interrupt work due to their need to protect themselves. Overall, the rapid lifting of measures should result in a reduction in expenditure of several hundred million Swiss francs  compared to the budgeted amounts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220218091949/https://www.admin.ch/gov/en/start/documentation/media-releases/media-releases-federal-council.msg-id-87216.html      All employees have protection under the short-time working scheme.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211130074141/https://www.arbeit.swiss/secoalv/en/home/menue/unternehmen/versicherungsleistungen/kurzarbeit-covid-19.html

As of 20.12, the Swiss government pays for tests (both anti-gen and PCR tests) that are needed for a COVID-19 certificate.    Test costs for certificates will be covered again  The Federal Council has also decided that the costs of certain Covid-19 tests that lead to a Covid certificate will be covered again in future. In doing so, he is implementing a parliamentary decision in the Covid 19 law. Rapid antigen tests and saliva PCR pool tests are to be paid for. Self-tests, individual PCR tests and antibody tests are not paid for. The costs of individual PCR tests for people with symptoms of illness, for contact persons and after positive pool samples are also covered. The new test cost system will apply from tomorrow, Saturday, December 18, 2021. From January 17, 2022, everyone who takes part in repetitive tests must also be able to obtain a test certificate.    Only one test upon entry for vaccinated and recovered people  After consulting the cantons, the Federal Council has also adjusted the test regime upon entry, which will apply from Monday, December 20, 2021. Before entering Switzerland, in addition to PCR tests that are not are older than 72 hours, rapid antigen tests that are not older than 24 hours are also accepted. The obligation to have a second test 4 to 7 days after entering Switzerland is waived for vaccinated and recovered people.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211221065541/https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-86544.html

Entry where a certificate is required has strict criteria around the process placed upon venue owners.    Entry checks with the COVID certificate  When letting people in, it is important that event organisers check the validity of the COVID certificate via COVID Certificate Check and always check against matching photo identification (e.g. ID card, passport, driving licence, residence permit, student card). In addition, organisers of large-scale events must obtain a cantonal permit. The COVID certificate is the only permissible document for entry. This applies to both the Swiss COVID certificate and to recognised foreign certificates (e.g. the EU Digital COVID Certificate). Youâll find more information for checkers and issuers on the COVID certificate on the corresponding page.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Masks must be worn in publicly accessible indoor spaces, for example in shops or in enclosed areas of public vehicles. Further details can be found on the Masks page. The general rule of thumb applies: Always wear a mask indoors when you are away from home and you are unable to maintain social distancing of 1.5 metres from other people at all times.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

26/2/22  On 17th February most restrictions were lifted by the federal government    Masks  In enclosed areas of public vehicles as well as in publicly accessible indoor areas of hospitals and clinics, retirement and care homes, people age 12 and over must wear masks. Youâll find more detailed information on the Masks page.    Wearing of masks compulsory throughout Switzerland  The mask-wearing requirement applies throughout Switzerland on public transport and in hospitals, clinics, retirement and care homes. Besides the nationwide rules, the cantons can make wearing masks compulsory in additional areas and situations. For this reason you must always follow the cantonal rules.   Wearing of masks compulsory on public transport and on planes  You must wear a mask in enclosed areas of the following public transport services and facilities:  Trains, trams and buses  Mountain railways, cable cars and chair lifts  Ships and boats  Aircraft (all scheduled and chartered flights taking off or landing in Switzerland)  Note: Masks are compulsory at all times, no matter how many people are travelling. If you refuse to wear a mask on public transport, you may be asked by the transport staff to get off at the next stop. If you refuse to do so, you may receive a fine. You may remove your mask briefly to eat or drink on public transport.     Wearing of masks compulsory in publicly accessible areas  To protect particularly vulnerable people, in certain situations masks must be worn in publicly accessible indoor areas of hospital, clinics, retirement and care homes.   Wearing of masks compulsory at work  Your employer has a duty to protect you. For this reason you should find out from your employer what requirements apply in terms of mask-wearing. You will find more information on the SECO website (in German).  Exemptions from the requirement to wear a mask  Children under the age of 12 do not have to wear a mask (cantonal exemptions may apply). Masks are available in childrenâs sizes. Adult masks can also be folded and the straps shortened to fit childrenâs faces (recommended for surgical masks).  General exemptions from the requirement to wear a mask on public transport and in hospitals, clinics, retirement and care homes. In the following cases, you do not have to wear a mask (regardless of your age):  You can prove that you are unable to wear a mask for a specific reason. Such reasons include, for example, facial injuries, shortness of breath, conditions such as dementia and Alzheimerâs, anxiety when wearing a mask and disabilities that make wearing a mask intolerable or impossible. All medical grounds must be substantiated with a certificate from a doctor or psychotherapist. You will find detailed information in the factsheet from the FBED and FOPH on mask dispensing for certain people with disabilities in the Documents tab.  You are a patient in a hospital or clinic: You can take off your mask when you are in your room(s).  You are resident in a retirement or care home.  Masks in everyday life  In any situation in which you want to give yourself and others additional protection you can decide for yourself whether you want to wear a mask even if doing so is not compulsory. Itâs still recommended to wear a mask particularly in enclosed and poorly ventilated spaces.    https://archive.fo/yREMb

https://archive.ph/ML7FX#selection-143.15-147.20  A travel ban is in place for countries with widespread occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 virus variants of concern (referred to as areas of variant of concern). Transport companies, e.g. air carriers and railway companies, may not transport any persons from these countries to Germany. There are only a few, strictly defined exceptions to this travel ban, namely for:  German citizens and persons who are resident in Germany with a current right to reside in the country, as well as their spouses, partners (if entering Germany from outside the EU or the United Kingdom / Northern Ireland: only partners living in the same household) and minor children  persons catching a connecting flight who do not leave the transit zone of a passenger airport and  few other special cases.  Persons qualifying for these exceptions must nevertheless complete a digital entry registration before entering the country, undergo mandatory testing or provide proof of immunity, and comply with the applicable quarantine regulations for travellers entering the country.

People are fully vaccinated or previously infected and able to document this, for example with a corona passport,  can enter from all countries without test or self-isolation.    FOR THE UNVACCINATED OR THOSE WHO WERE PREVIOUSLY UNINFECTED:    - Entry from countries in EU/Schengen: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from COVID-19 risk countries: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from all other countries (high risk countries): A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry within 24 hours after entry. Furthermore, there is self-isolation for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. Certain travellers (e.g. children under 15) are exempt from test and isolation requirements.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053540/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

People are fully vaccinated or previously infected and able to document this, for example with a corona passport,  can enter from all countries without test or self-isolation.    FOR THE UNVACCINATED OR THOSE WHO WERE PREVIOUSLY UNINFECTED:    - Entry from countries in EU/Schengen: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from COVID-19 risk countries: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from all other countries (high risk countries): A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry within 24 hours after entry. Furthermore, there is self-isolation for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. Certain travellers (e.g. children under 15) are exempt from test and isolation requirements.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053540/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

For those who are vaccinated or previously infected, there are no travel restrictions when entering Denmark.    For those are not vaccinated or previously infected:  - There are no travel restrictions if you enter from EU or Schengen countries .  - Those entering from a country outside EU and Schengen, must take a test at a test centre within 24 hours upon entry (self-tests are not valid for this purpose).      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220306181909/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

From 1 February 2022 there are no longer any restrictions in the social and elderly area. Thus there are no longer a requirement for corona passport for visitors etc. and requirements for the use of face mask or shield for visitors, etc. and employees on social services, etc.     If possible it is urged to continue arrangements for the display of corona passport and for the use of face mask/shield in nursing homes and social services with vulnerable residents/users. It is also urged with a continued focus on the test effort in relation to employees in the elderly care and on social services as well as visitors to nursing homes and social services.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

From 1 February 2022 there are no longer any restrictions in the social and elderly area. It is also urged with a continued focus on the test effort in relation to employees in the elderly care and on social services as well as visitors to nursing homes and social services.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

If you have had close contact with a COVID-19 case and you are not vaccinated with a complete vaccination regimen, you should quarantine: if you have had close contact with a patient with COVID-19 or someone suspected of having it without adequate protective measures, from 48 hours before the onset of symptoms, you should quarantine for 7 days staying in your home or place of accommodation, preferably in a room on your own. During the following 10 days after the last contact, protection measures should be stepped up (use of masks, limiting the number of social contacts, etc).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220311053730/https://www.spth.gob.es/faq?tab=2

If you have had close contact with a COVID-19 case and you are not vaccinated with a complete vaccination regimen, you should quarantine: if you have had close contact with a patient with COVID-19 or someone suspected of having it without adequate protective measures, from 48 hours before the onset of symptoms, you should quarantine for 7 days staying in your home or place of accommodation, preferably in a room on your own. During the following 10 days after the last contact, protection measures should be stepped up (use of masks, limiting the number of social contacts, etc).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220315234253/https://www.spth.gob.es/faq?tab=2

In general education, masks are recommended but covid-certificates are not mandatory.  In informal education and catering establishments, students must either be vaccinated, recovered or present a negative test (tests are accepted only for those under 18).     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306190941/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/education-pre-schools-hobby-education-sport-continuous-education/restrictions-in-education-youth-work-hobby-and-sports-activities

COVID-19 certificate or proof of recovery is required to attend events and activities taking place indoor. Unvaccinated person could still go to work if employer agree upon risk analysis. Mask wearing is recommended in the work environment.     In commercial and service establishments, the persons responsible for the operations, the service providers and traders on whose sales or service area the person is have to monitor that the obligation to wear a mask is adhered to. The service provider or trader has the right to not allow entry to their sales or service area to a person who refuses to wear a mask.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306191605/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306203523/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/work-during-the-emergency-situation

Public meetings and events are allowed but participants who are 18 years old and older have to prove that they do not pose an infection risk by presenting a COVID certificate stating vaccination or recovery.  For children of 12 of 18, negative tests are accepted for their COVID certificate.  Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306191605/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#mask

All persons 18 years of age and older must present a COVID certificate proving vaccination or recovery in order to participate in activities taking place in checked public spaces. A COVID certificate has to be presented to participate in sports, training, youth work, hobby activities and informal education, refresher training; at sports competitions, and sports and exercise events; in saunas, spas, water parks and swimming pools; at public meetings and events, including at the theatre, at the cinema, at a concert (including a church concert), at a conference; at museums and exhibition facilities; at entertainment services; at catering establishments in order to eat and drink on the premises.    For everyone, masks are mandatory in public spaces indoors and distance working is recommended.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306191605/https://www.kriis.ee/en/covid-crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#mask
Masks must be worn in public transport  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306205713/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/public-services-and-everyday-life/public-transport-within-estonia
No stay at home requirements   https://web.archive.org/web/20220306210600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life
No restriction on internal movement.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306210600/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life

Depending of the country of origin, the list of requirement changes. Travelers might have to get tested, self-isolate and might need to present an imperial reason to be allowed to enter Estonia (work, studying, family reasons, or under a special permit). Those who are fully vaccinated are exempt from these measures.    There's no particular testing or quarantine requirement for vaccinated persons / persons who have previously been infected with the COVID-19 disease.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220306215934/https://www.kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/who-subject-restrictions
No financial support, except for sick leave.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306220829/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/incapacity-benefit-payments---sick-days-care-leave
No relief found.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306220829/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/work-economy-and-business/incapacity-benefit-payments---sick-days-care-leave
A government website keep the public informed  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306222412/https://www.kriis.ee/en

It is possible to test for the coronavirus both for free (with a referral) and by paying. Free testing is provided for people who are symptomatic. It is possible to get a referral to testing by calling the Family Doctor.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220306222652/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/testing-for-the-virus
Contact tracing is done with the HOIA mobile app.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220306223204/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/hoia-mobile-app

A protective mask is obligatory in public indoor spaces (including rooms where COVID certificate is checked, e.g. cinema, theatre, events, trainings etc). Wearing a mask is not obligatory in activities where it is not possible, for instance, in direct sports and when coming in contact with water, as well as when eating on the premises of restaurants.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220306223335/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/personal-protection-equipment---masks-and-similar

All residents of Estonia from the age of 12 are recommended to get vaccinated for free against COVID-19.  A parent can book an appointment for their child aged 5-11 to get vaccinated by contacting the child's family doctor.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306223654/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/covid-19-vaccination/vaccination-in-estonia

Recommendations are made to protect elderly people.   Where possible, home-based services provided for the elderly by the local government of residence should be preferred to placement in a nursing home.  Residents of nursing homes should not be transferred between different homes.  Before meeting a person at risk, make sure you are safe from infection and ensure safety when meeting them: wear a mask, keep your distance, and clean your hands and surfaces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220306224037/https://www.kriis.ee/en/sickness-health-vaccinations/coronavirus-and-preventing-its-spread/prevention-coronavirus

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

The National Telework recommendation was officially ended on the 28th of February. It is now advised to shift to a combination of in-office and remote work gradually while maintaining the standard hygiene practices. The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210820141655/https://koronavilkku.fi/en

No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

On return from the Winter holidays (either 21 February, 28 February or 7 March, depending on the region of the country - https://web.archive.org/web/20220216093310/https://www.education.gouv.fr/calendrier-scolaire-100148) the health protocol applied to schools moves from Level 3 to Level 2.     Three main changes now apply:     - The end of the obligation to wear a mask outdoors for elementary school students and staff;  - The possibility of practicing physical and sports activities indoors again without wearing a mask (respecting a distance: contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask);  - The lightening of the rules limiting social mixing (by level or group of classes rather than by class), especially during break times.    In addition, legal guardians of students who have been in contact with a confirmed Covid-19 case in their class will no longer be obliged to send a signed "Declaration of Honour" that their child has completed the proscribed regime of self-testing in order for them to return to school after isolation, and that testing regime will be relaxed to one self-test rather than two from 28 February.     There are no reported policy changes for colleges and Universities.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220225010222/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change in policy yet implemented, but it was announced elementary, middle and high schools will all move from Level 2 to Level 1 protocol from 14 March and that requirements for staff to wear masks indoors in middle and high schools will end on this date. https://web.archive.org/web/20220311170328/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

From 16 February, restrictions that banned standing concerts, consumption while standing in bars or cafes, and that enforced the closure of discotheques and nightclubs were lifted and such venues were allowed to re-open, subject to the provisions of the Vaccine Pass - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071002/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    Under the provisions of the Vaccine Pass, all customers and employees who interact with the public in places of leisure and culture, commercial catering establishments, trade fairs and exhibitions, on long-distance inter-regional transport, at ski lifts or in tourist accommodation must posses a vaccine pass. Vaccination is also mandatory for all employees and service providers in health and medico-social establishments - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071010/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal
No cahnge in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220225003224/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

From 12 February, the classification of countries from which travelers are subject to differentiated border controls based on health indicators is as follows:     - "Green" countries and territories: countries or territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan and Vanuatu.  - "Orange" countries: countries in which there is an active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions, without diffusion of worrying variants. These are not all countries included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries.  - "Red" countries: countries in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. Currently, there are no countries classified as "red".  - "Scarlet red" countries: countries in which a particularly active circulation of the virus and the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape are observed. Currently, there is no country classified as "scarlet red".    In orer to enter France, travelers must comply with rules specific to their country of departure:     1: travelers from a country/territory classified as "green"  - Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a PCR test of less than 72 hours or antigenic test (TAG) of less than 48 hours.  - This obligation does not apply to the travel of road transport professionals in the exercise of their activity and to the following trips by land:  -- Journeys of less than 24 hours within a perimeter defined by a radius of 30 kilometres around the place of residence;  -- Business travel whose urgency or frequency is incompatible with the performance of a test or screening examination.    2: Travellers from a country/territory classified as "orange": all countries/territories other than those mentioned in paragraph 1 ("green")  Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a PCR test of less than 72 hours or antigenic test (TAG) of less than 48 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    In addition:     - vaccinated travellers (full vaccination schedule) are not subject to the regime of compelling reasons.  - unvaccinated travellers are subject to the imperative grounds regime and will have to commit to a 7-day self-isolation and undergo a test at the end of this period. The list of compelling reasons is specified in the travel and travel certificate issued by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    Whilst no countries are currently specified as Red or Scarlet Red, nnvaccinated travellers from these countries/territories would still be subject to the regime of compelling reasons for entering France, must present at boarding a negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight, will be subject to a mandatory antigen test upon arrival, and would be subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine,controlled by the security forces.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220213064422/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19     The specific rule requiring travelers from the United Kingdom to present results of a Covid-19 test taken within 24 hours of departure (rather than the usual 48 hours requires for travelers from other Orange list countries) has been rescinded as of 12 February. https://web.archive.org/web/20220213064422/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19 and https://web.archive.org/web/20220221213430/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/france/entry-requirements

From 16 February, the categorisation of Green / Orange list countries has been updated as follows:     "Green" countries/territories : countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Bahrain, Cape Verde, Cambodia, Colombia, South Korea, CÃ´te d'Ivoire, Cuba, The United Arab Emirates, Ecuador, Gabon, Ghana, Guinea, Equatorial Guinea, Guinea, Honduras, Hong Kong, Fiji, Mauritius, Samoa, Islands, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, Laos, Mauritania, Morocco, Nepal, Chad, New Zealand, Nicaragua, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, Vanuatu, Venezuela and Vietnam.    "Orange" countries/territories : countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" countries/territories.    There are currently no countries categorised as Red or Scarlet Red.     Entry regulations applicable to travelers from these countries are unchanged. https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071051/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Some relaxation in facial covering requirements, as from 21 February as schools return from Winter holidays (21 or 28 February, or 7 March depending on region) masks no longer need to be worn outdoors by elementary school students and staff. Face coverings are also no longer required for indoor school physical and sports activities where social distancing is possible (so, contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask). https://web.archive.org/web/20220221070953/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    Face coverings are still required on public transport and in some enclosed public spaces such as stadiums, concert halls, and theaters - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071002/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Some relaxation in facial covering requirements, as from 21 February as schools return from Winter holidays (21 or 28 February, or 7 March depending on region) masks no longer need to be worn outdoors by elementary school students and staff. Face coverings are also no longer required for indoor school physical and sports activities where social distancing is possible (so, contact sports are therefore not allowed without a mask). https://web.archive.org/web/20220225010222/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    Face coverings are still required on public transport and in some enclosed public spaces such as stadiums, concert halls, and theaters, but will be further relaxed from 28 February when face masks will no longer be required in places accessible by Vaccine Pass holders - https://web.archive.org/web/20220225003224/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over, with one parent's permission required for children aged between 5 and 11.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     Vaccination is mandatory for all staff of medical and medico-social institutions (including administrative staff), supporting services, and those who work in contact with frail people.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071212/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is mandatory for all those who work in contact with frail people. Thus, since September 15, 2021, the following must be vaccinated:    - all staff (including administrative staff) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, autonomous residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - home helpers working with people affecting APA or PCH, in home services or as employees of individual employers;  - staff of medical transport companies (including taxis under agreement);  - all professions in Book IV of the CSP, whether or not under agreement, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - all health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - occupational health service personnel.    Persons justifying a contraindication to vaccination are exempt from the vaccination obligation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221071212/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Maximum gatherings  A maximum of 100 people can gather in one place. If the circumstances allow it, more people can gather, provided that there is enough space:  Standing: at least 4 square meters per person  Sitting: at least 2 square meters per person  Example: in a 500 square meter room, 125 people can gather standing, or 250 people sitting.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220209040107/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

Rules for non-vaccinated changed on 11 February, meaning that non-vaccinated people do not need to quarantine upon arrival in the UK. Rules as follows:    Fully vaccinated â from 11 February  If you qualify as fully vaccinated for travel to England, you:    will not need to take a COVID-19 test before you travel to England or after you arrive  will not need to quarantine when you arrive  You will need to complete a passenger locator form before you travel to England.    Check if you can follow the rules for people who are fully vaccinated â includes people aged 17 and under.    Not fully vaccinated â from 11 February  If you do not qualify as fully vaccinated for travel to England, you will need to:    show proof of a negative COVID-19 test â test to be taken in the 2 days before you travel to England  book and pay for a COVID-19 PCR test â to be taken after you arrive in England  complete a passenger locator form before you travel to England  You will need to book the PCR test before you travel.    You will not need to quarantine, unless the result of the PCR test is positive.      http://web.archive.org/web/20220210131053/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19    http://web.archive.org/web/20220211134511/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19

24 February    Fully vaccinated: Before you travel to England you must complete a passenger locator form. You need to do this in the 48 hours before you arrive in England.    Not fully vaccinated: Must complete PCR test but from 24 February, there is no legal requirement to self-isolate if you get a positive day 2 test result.      http://web.archive.org/web/20220224030744/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19    http://web.archive.org/web/20220225155734/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/travel-to-england-from-another-country-during-coronavirus-covid-19

A negative PCR test is required to enter Georgia unless a passenger is fully vaccinated and arriving by air. Unvaccinated passengers will additionally have to submit a travel history in advance of entering Georgia and take another PCR test on day 3 of arrival in Georgia.The requirement to self-isolate is terminated for unvaccinated visitors who are citizens or residents of listed countries provided the above conditions are met.   Travelers arriving by land or sea must be citizens or residents of listed countries and travel must be directly from a listed country. Greece will reopen schools as scheduled on Monday amid record coronavirus cases, the government has decided.    Schools will reopen on Jan. 10 with stricter testing protocols as ânothing can replace live teaching for the psycho-emotional development of our children,â Education Minister Niki Kerameus said Tuesday.    https://web.archive.org/web/%2A/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-01-04/greece-to-reopen-schools-as-planned-on-monday-amid-record-cases

Greece reintroduced measures aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus pandemic amid concern that rising cases will pile pressure on the nationâs health care system.    As much as 50% of all private and public-sector employees will have to work from home between Jan. 3 and Jan. 16, Health Minister Athanasios Plevris said Monday. The government also ordered restaurants, bars, cafes and night clubs to close at midnight.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161816/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=ea7e0e9d-7230-11ec-a53d-5a7175777570&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0xMi0yNy9ncmVlY2UtcmVpbnN0YXRlcy13b3JrLWZyb20taG9tZS1tYW5kYXRlLW5pZ2h0LWxpZmUtY3VyYnM=

The government last week reimposed a mask mandate for all indoor and outdoor spaces and canceled outdoor holiday festivities. A highly protective mask, or the use of double mask, will now be mandatory for those working in restaurants, Plevris said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161816/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=ea7e0e9d-7230-11ec-a53d-5a7175777570&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0xMi0yNy9ncmVlY2UtcmVpbnN0YXRlcy13b3JrLWZyb20taG9tZS1tYW5kYXRlLW5pZ2h0LWxpZmUtY3VyYnM=

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

Guidelines for primary schools, day care institutions and recreational activities:  -In the case of infection at schools and institutions etc., it will most often be other contacts that are of concern.  -Children, who are other contacts to an infected person (child or employee) in a day-care nursery etc., in school (including boarding schools and private schools) or in connection with recreational activities, must follow the recommendations for other contacts. Learn more in the section If you are an other contact.  -However, roommates at boarding schools etc., must follow the guidelines for close contacts.  Last updated Wednesday 9. february  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129063601/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/guidelines-for-primary-schools-day-care-and-after-school-activities/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -Special rules apply if you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks. Read more in the section âPreviously infected with COVID-19â here.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccine to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -If you are not a resident in Greenland, you must bring documentation that you are fully vaccinated.  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must bring a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must show a lease, employment contract or something else that documents your move  https://web.archive.org/web/20220201102406/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.    Requirements to enter Greenland by air or sea:  People who are 12 years old or older must be able to document one of the following things in order to enter Greenland by air or sea:  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must document this with a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency. You can download your certificate of residence at sullissivik.gl.  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must be able to document that you have a job or a home in Greenland. For example, you can use a rental contract, a contract of employment or a letter from your coming employer as proof.  -If you are not a resident of Greenland you must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and able to provide documentation proving this.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated. Only vaccines approved by EMA are accepted.  -Furthermore, you must live up to the rules on use of face masks during travel to Greenland.  Last updated Wednesday 2. march  https://archive.ph/dDMhY

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.    Requirements to enter Greenland by air or sea:  People who are 12 years old or older must be able to document one of the following things in order to enter Greenland by air or sea:  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must document this with a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency. You can download your certificate of residence at sullissivik.gl.  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must be able to document that you have a job or a home in Greenland. For example, you can use a rental contract, a contract of employment or a letter from your coming employer as proof.  -If you are not a resident of Greenland you must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and able to provide documentation proving this.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated. Only vaccines approved by EMA are accepted.  -Furthermore, you must live up to the rules on use of face masks during travel to Greenland.  Last updated Wednesday 2. march  https://archive.ph/dDMhY

If you test positive:  Test result  -If your test result is positive, it means you are infected with the coronavirus.  -If your result from a PCR-test is positive, you will receive your test result via SMS. You are responsible for contacting your close contacts. Read more about the definition of a close contact.  -If you have taken an antigen test (home test) which shows a positive result, you should consider yourself infected with COVID-19. You must follow the same guidelines, but you will not be contacted by the health department / corona secretariat.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215024602/https://corona.nun.gl/en/infection-and-symptoms/if-you-test-positive/

Domestic travel in Greenland:  -Face masks  It is not required to wear a face mask on domestic flights in Greenland.  Last updated Friday 11. february    Use of face masks and visors  -Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.    In Greenland, you MUST wear a face mask in the following situations:  -All individuals aged 12 years or older on international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  -If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129080932/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

Good advice for people at a higher risk:  -In general, if you are someone who is at a higher risk, you can continue to do the things you did before the COVID-19 pandemic, e.g. go to work, participate in leisure activities and take care of your grandchildren.  -If before the COVID-19 pandemic, you had to follow special precautions in your daily life to avoid being infected with an infectious disease, e.g. you have a special condition and are immunocompromised, you should continue to follow those precautions.    The National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) recommends the following for persons who are at a higher risk:  -Get re-vaccinated  -Follow the recommendations from the Office of the Medical Director of Health and ask others to be mindful  -Avoid large events and gatherings of people where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider using a face mask in public spaces where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider talking with your workplace about how to ensure that you can go to work safely    The older you are â the more and more serious chronic diseases have â the more attention you need to pay to following the recommendations. You must naturally take your quality of life into consideration, when you place limits on your life.  *Risk groups and highly vulnerable people  https://web.archive.org/web/20220215030314/https://corona.nun.gl/en/information-about-covid-19/
