No change in policy.  Self-testing on SARS-CoV-2 rapid antigen tests is voluntary and free and is performed once a week. Although it is recommended that students self-test on Mondays before school (or Sundays before bedtime), testing can be done on another day of the school-specific week, depending on when the first test is delivered to each school. It is important that the self-test is performed once a week and that the interval between the two tests is equal. For example, parents / guardians may record a negative test result in a student's notebook presented by the student at school or may report it in another way determined by the school.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219124852/https://www.koronavirus.hr/upute-ravnateljima-o-primjeni-modela-ukidanja-samoizolacija-u-osnovnim-i-srednjim-skolama-uz-provodenje-redovitog-dobrovoljnog-samotestiranja-ucenika/1004

It is important that the self-test is performed once a week and that the interval between the two tests is equal. For example, parents / guardians may record a negative test result in a student's notebook presented by the student at school or may report it in another way determined by the school.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219124852/https://www.koronavirus.hr/upute-ravnateljima-o-primjeni-modela-ukidanja-samoizolacija-u-osnovnim-i-srednjim-skolama-uz-provodenje-redovitog-dobrovoljnog-samotestiranja-ucenika/1004

No change in policy.  In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interfering with workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220206191121/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-poslu/46

Professional artistic performances, cultural programs and events attended only by persons (visitors, performers and staff) holding an EU digital COVID certificate of vaccination, testing and / or recovery from COVID-19 are exempt from all restrictions of this recommendation - including the obligation to wear masks, physical distances, number of persons present, etc. Also, if all contractors have an EU digital COVID certificate, they are exempt from all anti-epidemic measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219124748/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/preporuke-za-sprjecavanje-zaraze-covid-19-tijekom-odrzavanja-profesionalnih-umjetnickih-izvedbi-kulturnih-programa-i-manifestacija/740

No change in policy.  The necessary epidemiological measure of self-isolation is automatically determined for all passengers in transit, including personnel in the transport sector, if they do not leave the Republic of Croatia within 12 hours from the moment of entering the Republic of Croatia.    Citizens of EU Member States (including Croatian citizens), i.e. Schengen Member States and Schengen associated countries, as well as members of their families and third-country nationals who are long-term residents under Council Directive 2003/109/EC of 25 November 2003 concerning the status of third-country nationals who are long-term residents and persons entitled to reside under other EU directives or national law or who have national long-term visas and are coming from third countries, must present a valid EU Digital COVID Certificate when entering the Republic of Croatia.    Exceptionally, the abovementioned category of passengers who do not yet possess an EU Digital COVID Certificate will be allowed entry into the Republic of Croatia if they have the following:     negative PCR test result or rapid antigen test result - RAT for SARS-CoV-2, where the RAT test must be listed in the Common list of rapid antigen tests recognized by the Member States of the European Union, published by the European Commission. If the RAT test results were made abroad, the manufacturer and/or the commercial name of the test must be visible. Otherwise, it will not be accepted as credible for entering the Republic of Croatia.  The PCR test result must not be older than 72 hours and the RAT test result must not be older than 24 hours, counting from the time the test was taken until the arrival at the border crossing point;   certificate that they have received two doses of vaccine used in the EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax) or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since receiving the second dose of the vaccine, or a certificate that they have received one dose of the vaccine if the vaccine is administered in a single dose (Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose, or a certificate that they have received the booster dose of the vaccine;  certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States (Pfizer, Moderna, AstaZeneca, Gamaleya, Sinopharm, Novavax, Janssen/Johnson&Johnson) or a vaccine approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use (Serum Institute of India - Covishield, Bharat Biotech - Covaxin, Sinovac - CoronaVac), provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 270 days from their arrival at the border crossing point;  positive PCR test result or rapid antigen test result, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 180 days and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or  a medical certificate of recovery;  or if they perform PCR testing or rapid antigen testing - RAT for SARS-CoV-2 immediately upon their arrival in the Republic of Croatia (at their own expense), with the obligation to stay in self-isolation until they obtain a negative test result. In case they cannot get tested, they have to self-isolate for seven (7) days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219130513/https://mup.gov.hr/uzg-covid/english/286212

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Croatia? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes  A test can be arranged at the following locations:?COVID-19 Testing Locations in Croatia.  The cost of a local test (rapid antigen test or a PCR test) ranges from $40 to $150 or more, depending upon the location, and the result can be expected between 1-48 hours depending upon the type of the test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219125454/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy.  Has the government of Croatia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Croatia for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in Croatia? PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220219125454/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Modern vaccine is intended for the prevention of COVID-19 disease in people 12 years of age and older.  It is currently not recommended to give Comirnaty to children under 12 years of age    https://web.archive.org/web/20220118084040/https://www.koronavirus.hr/o-cijepljenju/329
Schools are fully open.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228190945/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

Employers are allowed to require their employees to be vaccinated, either as a standard working condition for all workers or as an individual working condition, depending on the job. For workers who have not yet been vaccinated, the employer may set a deadline of 45 days for taking the first vaccination. Vaccination is expected in the public sector, and mayors can decide on it.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

All indoor events and outdoor events with more than 500 people attending require an immunity certificate. This certificate is provided to all those who have received their first vaccine dose). It is valid for six months after the second vaccination, after which it will only be extended is the third booster dose has been given. After the third booster dose, the certificate will be valid indefinitely.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191612/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/coronavirus

Events of more than 500 people can only be attended by those with an immunity certificate. This certificate is provided to all those who have received their first vaccine dose). It is valid for six months after the second vaccination, after which it will only be extended is the third booster dose has been given. After the third booster dose, the certificate will be valid indefinitely.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191612/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/coronavirus & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Masks are required on all public transport, and proof of immunity is also required on some means of public transport.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228193937/https://wiki.unece.org/display/CTRBSBC/Hungary & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

There is no curfew. People who suspect they have the virus are asked to stay at home and avoid going out into the community.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

No restrictions on internal movement. Whilst proof of immunity is required on some means of public transport, there is no physical restriction on unvaccinated people moving within Hungary.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228193937/https://wiki.unece.org/display/CTRBSBC/Hungary & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

People entering Hungary must agree to enter mandatory quarantine unless one of the following applies:  - You are in possession a Hungary issued Immunity Certificate, EU Covid certificate, or obtain UK proof of vaccination (final dose must have been administered at least 14 days prior to travel)  - You have a negative PCR test from the past 72 hours  - You are arriving by road, rail and waterway from one of Hungaryâs neighbouring countries,  - You meet one of the exemptions for vaccination  It is possible to leave quarantine early following two negative COVID-19 tests within 5 days of each other but at least 48 hours apart.  Unless you are a Hungarian national, or arriving on land from a neighbouring country, people entering Hungary will be subject to a temperature check on arrival.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228194631/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/entry-requirements

Several measures are in place:  - parents receive a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child will be refunded their income tax paid in 2021 up to the average wage tax level.  - Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium of HUF 80,000 in November and will receive a full refund  of their 13-month pension in February 2022 .  - Wage increases will continue: from January 2022, the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000 and the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  - Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax from January 2022.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, public employees can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
Up to date information is available via a publicly available website.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Anyone suspected of having COVID-19 can order a test through their GP or a hospital for free. Outside of this, the officially regulated price for a PCR test is 19,500 HUF, with antigen tests being offered from 8,500 to 15,000 HUF. Some facilities offer express results for an additional fee.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191128/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

A contract tracing app (VirusRadar) was launched in May 2020, but there is no evidence of its broad or consistent use.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228195241/https://nextsense.com/ns-newsarticle-virusradar-a-mobile-contact-tracing-implemented.nspx

Masks are required in most indoor spaces, including inside retail establishments, hotels, restaurants, theaters, cinemas, government buildings, medical facilities, and on public transport. They are not required outdoors.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191128/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Vaccines are generally available, with Pfizer, Moderna, Astra Zeneca, Sinopharm, Sputnik V all being used. Vaccination is now allowed for children over 5 years of age.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191128/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Visits to hospitals are not allowed. Visits to social care facilities are allowed, but it is mandatory to wear face masks.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191612/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/coronavirus
Vaccines are generally available, with Pfizer, Moderna, Astra Zeneca, Sinopharm, Sputnik V all being used.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228191128/https://hu.usembassy.gov/covid-19/
Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis
Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Three vaccines are required for health care and certain public administration workers, including government officials and educators.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220228192100/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

The Government has approved plans to remove almost all Covid-19 related restrictions next Monday (28th Feb)    In schools and childcare pods for children, staggered breaks and physical distancing can also end from Monday. These settings will still be required to practice good hygiene and have good ventilation, while children should stay at home if they are sick.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226075802/https://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/cabinet-agrees-to-drop-almost-all-remaining-covid-19-rules-from-monday-1.4808912

Since 1 February 2022, a standard acceptance period of 14 days after the final dose in a primary vaccine series of a vaccine will be required for all vaccines accepted for travel to Ireland.    You are fully vaccinated when it is:    14 days after the second AstraZeneca dose or second Covishield dose  14 days after the second Pfizer-BioNtech dose  14 days after the second Moderna dose  14 days after the single Janssen dose  14 days after the second Sinopharm dose (also called Vero Cell Inactivated)  14 days after your second dose of Coronavac (Sinovac)  14 days after your second dose of Covaxin  14 days after your second dose of of Novavax (Nuvaxovid)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222092310/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/travel_and_recreation/travel_to_ireland/travel_to_ireland_during_covid.htmla

From 6 March 2022, all COVID-19 travel restrictions are removed. You no longer need to complete a passenger locator form. You also no longer need proof of vaccination or recovery, or a COVID-19 test.    You should follow public health advice if you develop symptoms of COVID-19 or if you are a close contact of a confirmed case of COVID-19.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220308070549/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/travel_and_recreation/travel_to_ireland/travel_to_ireland_during_covid.html

By law, you must wear a face covering when using public transport. This includes in taxis, as well as in bus and rail stations.    Mask wearing will still be required in the following settings:    public transport, taxis and at stations/airports/ports  retail premises (including shopping centres, libraries, cinemas, theatres, museums, post offices, banks, credit unions), public offices and at premises providing specified services and businesses (incl. salons, hairdressers, travel agents, laundries, dry cleaners, bookmakers)  workers in customer facing and food preparation roles in premises where food and beverages are sold for consumption on the premises  healthcare settings    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222092940/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/0fc0d-government-announces-that-most-of-the-public-health-measures-currently-in-place-can-be-removed/?referrer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gov.ie%2Fen%2Fpublication%2F3361b-public-health-updates%2F      From 28 February 2022, it is no longer mandatory to wear a face covering on public transport, in taxis, shops, schools and other indoor public areas. Staff in hospitality settings will no longer need to wear a face covering. . You are still recommended to wear a face mask in hospitals and health settings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222091958/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/face_coverings_during_covid19.html

The Government has approved plans to remove almost all Covid-19 related restrictions next Monday (28th Feb)    Under a plan that went to Cabinet, all legal requirements to wear masks will expire after February 28th, with their use only required in healthcare settings. People will be advised to exercise their own judgement on the use of masks in schools, in retail settings and on public transport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220226075802/https://www.irishtimes.com/news/health/cabinet-agrees-to-drop-almost-all-remaining-covid-19-rules-from-monday-1.4808912

28/02/22    Face masks  Face masks must be worn wherever the 1 meter social distancing rule cannot be observed between people who are unrelated.    Mask obligation does not apply to children born 2006 or later.    Face masks must be used where it is not possible to ensure 1 meter of social distancing, such as in healthcare services, museums, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities. Face mask needs to cover both nose and mouth.    Those who do not have the understanding or maturity to use a face mask correctly or are unable to do so for other reasons, such as health reasons, do not have to wear a mask.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220221212536/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

28/02/22    Effective restrictions on gatherings  As of Friday 25 February 2022 all public restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic will be lifted, both domestically and at the border.  Limits to the number of people at gatherings are none  Social distancing rules are none  Masks are not mandatory anywhere  Restrictions on any kind of operations are no longer applicable, neither the obligation to register guests nor restrictions on opening hours  Personal infection preventative measures are encouraged and if we experience symptoms we get tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228210608/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

From Jan 10th  for local public transport for everyone 12+ directives require travelers to exhibit a Super Green Pass (as a proof of vaccination or being recovered from Covid).  Capacity is still reduced to 80% for most types of transport and FFP2 masks are required for all travellers irrespective of vaccination status.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220107123924/https://qds.it/mascherine-chirurgiche-ffp2-utilizzo-durata-quando-cambiarle/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220111225241/https://www.ilrestodelcarlino.it/cronaca/green-pass-trasporti-scuolabus-1.7232508  https://web.archive.org/web/20211216150703/https://www.autoblog.it/post/stato-demergenza-fino-al-31-marzo-2022-super-green-pass-le-regole-per-i-trasporti

The number of orange zones is stable, in such zones curfews are in place except for the vaccinated and recently recovered from Covid (Super Green Pass).  Social distancing and masks are mandatory almost anywhere for everyone, including the vaccinated.  For regions that are classified as Yellow zones no curfews are in place. For most countries, except for European countries, it is mandatory to exhibit a negative test (antigen or PCR) in conjunction with a Super Green Pass (vaccinated or recovered), if this is not done people will only be admitted if they have residency or working permits, and will therefore have to self-quarantine. For tourism and without a proof of vaccination, it won't be possible to enter Italy from countries in the D & E list.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220219173252/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

For tourism and without a proof of vaccination, it won't be possible to enter Italy from countries in the D & E list.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220219173252/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

For tourism and without a proof of vaccination, it won't be possible to enter Italy from countries in the D & E list.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220219173252/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto

From March 1st almost all restrictions have been removed. The only restrictions still in place are to show a "green pass equivalent" certificate (so not a vaccine mandate).  Vaccinated people therefore just need to show their vaccination status, unvaccinated people need to show a negative test or proof or recent recovery from Covid. In case a proof of vaccination or recent recovery cannot be provided they will need to quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220303173230/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301212105/https://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/da-oggi-piu-facile-viaggiare-stop-quarantena-e-green-pass-base-chi-entra-italia-paesi-extra-ue-AEx0F3GB

From March 1st almost all travel restrictions have been removed. The only restrictions still in place are to show a "green pass equivalent" certificate (so not a vaccine mandate).  Vaccinated people therefore just need to show their vaccination status, unvaccinated people need to show a negative test or proof or recent recovery from Covid. In case a proof of vaccination or recent recovery cannot be provided they will need to quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220303173230/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto  https://web.archive.org/web/20220301212105/https://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/da-oggi-piu-facile-viaggiare-stop-quarantena-e-green-pass-base-chi-entra-italia-paesi-extra-ue-AEx0F3GB

11/3/22  Vaccination against the coronavirus has been started since February 1, 2021. What is meant here is the Russian âSputnik Vâ vaccine produced by Karaganda pharmaceutical complex. âSputnik Vâ is the world`s first registered vaccine for prevention of the coronavirus infection. It was developed in the N. Gamaleya National Research Center of Epidemiology and Microbiology under the Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation. The two-component vaccine was developed based on a human adenovirus vector. In Kazakhstan, the Russian vaccine is produced by Karaganda pharmaceutical complex. To be more precise, the substance is delivered from Russia while in Kazakhstan the substance is processed into a finished pharma product. Kazakhstani stocks and raw materials are used. Mass vaccination will start from March 2021. The vaccine won`t be provided free-of-charge to all the Kazakhstani citizens. The citizens can apply for a free-of-charge vaccination within the statutory free-of-charge medical assistance. The Kazakhstani vaccine is called QazCovid-in. That is an inactivated vaccine, which was developed in May 2020.    Who will be vaccinated first?    During the first stages, the vaccine will be provided to people from the risk categories. If the volume of the vaccine allows, then the rest of Kazakhstani citizens will also be able to get the vaccine.    The following individuals with a high risk of contracting the coronavirus infection (priority-based order) are subject to the vaccination against the coronavirus:    medical employees, first of all employees of infectious diseases hospitals, ambulances, resuscitation and intensive care units, health care organizations providing primary health care, emergency rooms of health care organizations providing inpatient care, employees of the sanitary and epidemiological service;  teachers;  district police officers;  students;  personnel of medical and social as well as private childcare centers;  employees of Emergency Situations Service, Ministry of Defense and Ministry of Internal Affairs, National Security Committee, State Security Service of the Republic of Kazakhstan;  employees of Presidential Affairs Department of the Republic of Kazakhstan, civil servants, citizens of the Republic of Kazakhstan working for the diplomatic and consular missions accredited in Kazakhstan, members of national teams;  people with the chronic diseases (diabetes, chronic obstructive     pulmonary and heart diseases).  Where the vaccination is performed?    Vaccination of citizens takes place in the vaccination facilities of local medical organizations.  Vaccination of specialized groups is performed at the place of service of a relevant agency.In certain cases (low population size, lack of a stationary vaccination premise, lack of refrigeration equipment with a low temperature regime), mobile vaccination facilities or mobile vaccination teams are arranged for vaccination.     A vaccination team is assembled in each vaccination facility with regard to a daily workload per 1 team, which is no more than 60 vaccines (for mobile teams no more than 40 vaccines).     Thus, 1 vaccination team consists of 1 doctor, 1 treatment nurse and 1 registrar if required.    In rural areas, a vaccination team can consist of 1 rural paramedic (if there is no doctor), 1 treatment nurse and 1 registrar if required.The vaccines that were done are registered in the established registration forms (a separate register of preventive vaccinations against COVID, a vaccination record card, a patient's medical record, a vaccination section of the medical information system) with indication of the date of vaccination, type of vaccination (component I or II), manufacturer, batch number, vaccine reaction.    It is planned that an electronic vaccination passport will be introduced.    An electronic vaccination passport is a document certifying that a person got preventive vaccines. It will provide information on medications a person received, doses, the dates and also, whether there were any reactions after a vaccination.       As soon as a person will get a vaccine against the coronavirus infection, information about it will become available in the eGov mobile app.     Who won`t be vaccinated against the coronavirus?    Vaccination against the coronavirus in Kazakhstan is contraindicated to children under 18 and people over 65 due to the lack of data on its efficiency and safety.    Individuals with permanent and temporary medical contraindications to the preventive vaccines are not subject to vaccination against COVID pursuant to the Order of Minister of Health of the Republic of Kazakhstan as of October 21, 2020 No. KR DSM-146/2020 âOn Approval of the List of Medical Contraindications to Carry Preventive Vaccinationsâ.     Patients receiving immunosuppressive treatment and patients with an immune deficiency may not develop a sufficient immune response. Therefore, taking drugs that suppress the function of the immune system is contraindicated for at least 1 month before and after vaccination due to the risk of decreased immunogenicity. Therefore, intake of medical products that suppress the immune system function is contraindicated for at least 1 month prior and after vaccination due to the risk of decreased immunogenicity.    Individuals suffering from an acute and symptomless COVID forms are not subject to vaccination.Individuals who had a contact with those suffering from infectious diseases, including COVID, get the vaccine after a quarantine.No screening is performed prior to vaccination to check antibodies against COVID (EIA and PCR research).  It is recommended to vaccinated those who suffered from any COVID forms in 6 months after convalescence with regard to health assessment prior to vaccination.       Can one withdraw from a vaccine?    It is possible to withdraw from the vaccine against the coronavirus. The vaccination is carried out on a voluntary basis with provision of consent by a person getting a vaccine.      Pursuant to the Article 77 of the Code of the Republic of Kazakhstan "On People's Health and Healthcare System", Kazakhstani citizens have a right to withdraw from preventive vaccines.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220311083700/https://egov.kz/cms/en/articles/health_care/Vakcinaciya-protiv-koronavirusnoy-infekcii-
https://web.archive.org/web/20220311083700/https://egov.kz/cms/en/articles/health_care/Vakcinaciya-protiv-koronavirusnoy-infekcii-
Free

5 July 2021 policy made public, but requirement for first dose delayed until 10 August 2021    The first dose of vaccines must have been administered for those groups who have been mandated to be vaccinated: service organizations (banking, financial, insurance, consulting and hotel organizations), wholesale and retail trade facilities, passenger transportations, airports, and communication and telecommunication facilities. employers will be required to provide the proof of vaccination for their employees    http://web.archive.org/web/20220109183220/https://www.dentons.com/en/insights/alerts/2021/july/2/kazakhstan-adopts-mandatory-vaccination-for-employees    http://web.archive.org/web/20220207131003/https://www.inform.kz/en/kazakhstan-sets-new-dates-for-mandatory-covid-19-vaccination_a3812606

Quote: "Travelers must provide a negative PCR test.  PCR tests must be taken no more than 72 hours before arrival into Kyrgyzstan.  If your PCR test expires en route due to flight delays or cancellations, you will be required to test again upon arrival at your own expense.  As of February 11, 2021, travelers may show their original vaccine card showing proof of  As of February 11, 2021, travelers may show their original vaccine card showing proof of vaccination against COVID-19 instead of a negative PCR test.  Travelers without vaccination or valid PCR results will be denied entry.  Children under age 5 are exempt from testing or vaccination entry requirements."    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20220217132813/https://kg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools are fully open. Masks and spit tests are available on a voluntary basis.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133458/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140102/https://www.regierung.li/files/attachments/20220216-Medienmitteilung-60-COVID-19-Regierung-hebt-Massnahamen-auf.pdf?t=637820888994325498

The work from home message has been lifted, though employers can still put protection measures such as masks or work from home recommendations in place as they see fit.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140102/https://www.regierung.li/files/attachments/20220216-Medienmitteilung-60-COVID-19-Regierung-hebt-Massnahamen-auf.pdf?t=637820888994325498
https://archive.vn/NSPIj  Restricitions to stay in place until 31st March according to the Swiss Government https://archive.vn/EUj0X

As of the 16th of February 2022, private and public events can be held and attended without Corona protection measures in place or COVID certificates required. There are no restrictions on private gatherings, though public gatherings with audience still have a cap of 1000 people.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140637/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/coronavirus

Public transport is operating. All over the age of 12 are required to wear a mask in trains, trams, and buses, as well as on mountain rail and cableways and on lake and river boats.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140405/https://ch.usembassy.gov/covid-19-info/

There are no recommendations or requirements to stay at home; people who test positive must still isolate for a period of at least 5 days.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus
There are no restrictions in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140405/https://ch.usembassy.gov/covid-19-info/

The same rules for entering Switzerland apply to entering Liechtenstein. You may only enter if you are fully vaccinated, with the final vaccine dose having been delivered in the past 270 days; if you are fully vaccinated, no negative test or entry form is required. If you are not fully vaccinated, and are not an EU, Swiss, or Liechtenstein national, or holder of a residency permit, you may not enter the country.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134613/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/de/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134849/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/entry-requirements

It is possible to apply for and receive short-time work compensation due to the economic consequences of the pandemic. This is officially in place until the end of March 2022, with the possibility of extension until June 2022.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305143517/https://www.serviceportal.li/de/medienmitteilungen/moeglichkeit-fuer-corona-bedingte-kurzarbeitsentschaedigung-soll-bis-juni-2022-verlaengert-werden & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305144018/https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-84116.html
No measures found.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus
No measures found.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

Up to date information is publicly available via the government website.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

The test centre in Vaduz in the Marktplatzgarage is open daily from 14:00 to 17:00. No appointment is necessary, and results are available within 24-36 hours. The test if free if you have health insurance, and you do not have to be symptomatic to order one.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305135408/https://www.regierung.li/coronavirus

Upon testing positive, people are asked to list their contacts whenever possible for "traceability purposes".  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/

Masks are now only required in health and care facilities and on public transport is above the age of 12.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305133605/https://tourismus.li/en/our-country/about-liechtenstein/current-information-on-covid-19-in-the-principality-of-liechtenstein/

Residents aged 5 and over can register for vaccination, with booster vaccines available for all those 12 and over. The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are being used.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305140637/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/coronavirus & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305141510/https://www.serviceportal.li/de/privatpersonen/gesundheit-vorsorge-und-pflege/coronavirus/anmeldung-covid-impfung

Before meeting someone who is high risk, including the elderly, it is recommended that a PCR or rapid antigen test is taken. Those who wish to particularly protect themselves are advised to limit close contact with others. Masks are required in retirement and nursing homes by guests. Per the Ministry of Economy and Innovation for Lithuania, When an enterprise declares inactivity due to an emergency or quarantine the worker shall receive at least the minimum monthly salary and shall not be required to arrive to work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220228181226/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-3/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-2/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus

Per the Ministry of Economy and Innovation, there is support for employee's salaries as well as subsidies if needed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314160851/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/lt/covid-19-pandemijos-valdymo-priemones  https://web.archive.org/web/20220314161317/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-1

Per the Ministry of Economy and Innovation for Lithuania, Emergency tax loans, with deferred taxes, including suspension of taxes and paying fines and interest on loans are deferred.  Also implemented programs to accelerate payments and fundings to business as well as addition date guarantees in order to create to supplement existing financial instruments.  Enabling municipalities to invest in projects.  The bank of Lithuania also increased lending limits and reduced capital requirements for credit.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220228181226/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-3/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-2/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus

Those with one of the following documents can enter Moldova without having to self-isolate.  - proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination, with second dose administered at least 14 days before arrival  - negative result of a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before time of arrival  - negative result of a rapid antigen test taken no more than 48 hours hours before time of arrival  - a confirmation of the presence of COVID-19 antibodies (serological test) that is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test  All those without this documentation must complete an online epidemiological form and self-isolate for 14 days. Self-isolation can stop after 7 days with a negative PCR or antigen test.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220219193312/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/moldova/coronavirus

Those with one of the following documents can enter Moldova without having to self-isolate.  - proof that you have received both doses of an approved vaccination, with second dose administered at least 14 days before arrival  - negative result of a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before time of arrival  - negative result of a rapid antigen test taken no more than 48 hours hours before time of arrival  - a confirmation of the presence of COVID-19 antibodies (serological test) that is valid for a period of 90 days from the date of the test  All those without this documentation must complete an online epidemiological form and self-isolate for 14 days. Self-isolation can stop after 7 days with a negative PCR or antigen test.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220224060715/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/moldova/coronavirus

"From Friday 18 February all locations in the Netherlands will be allowed to stay open until 01.00. Until 25 February, the coronavirus entry pass (3G) must be shown at locations where this is currently mandatory, such as restaurants, bars, cinemas, theatres and music venues and at professional sporting events. Once you are inside any of these locations, the rules on assigned seating, wearing a face mask and keeping 1.5 metres apart will no longer apply and capacity will no longer be limited. At locations accommodating more than 500 people, however, assigned seating and face masks will still be mandatory. "  https://archive.fo/M1c8X#selection-155.0-155.611

"On Friday 25 February we will take the final step. From then, opening times will return to normal and we will lift the following requirements: showing a coronavirus entry pass (3G) at locations accommodating fewer than 500 people, staying 1.5 metres apart, wearing face masks while walking around bars and restaurants, schools and shops, having a limited number of visitors, and assigned seating in bars, restaurants and other venues. That means that large night clubs, discotheques, festivals and events can open up without limitations. At indoor locations accommodating more than 500 people where there is no assigned seating, for example night clubs and festivals, everyone must show a negative test result. This does not apply at events where there is a continuous flow of visitors, such as trade fairs and conferences. To ensure that vulnerable people are able to travel safely, the requirement to wear a face mask on public transport and at airports will remain in force even after 25 February."  https://archive.fo/M1c8X#selection-163.0-166.0

Education  From Thursday, January 27 to February 18, 2022, students of grades 5-8 of primary schools and all grades of secondary schools take classes in a remote form. Students in grades 1-4 of primary schools continue their education in a full-time mode.    From February 21, 2022, all students will return to full-time education.     Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules.    Nurseries and kindergartens  Nurseries and kindergartens are open and provide care for children.    Illness, quarantine or isolation of the child  A person covered by sickness insurance is entitled to an allowance in the event of necessity to care for a sick child, including when the child has been subject to isolation or quarantine. Care allowance may also be used by a parent who has to look after a healthy child up to the age of 8 due to the unexpected closure of the institution the child attends.    You can learn more about the care allowance on the ZUS website .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211112845/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja

25/2/22  All students have returend to school.    From February 21, 2022, all students returned to full-time education.     Detailed information is available on the website of the Ministry of Education and Science .    Find out more about general school rules.    Face masks are still required    https://web.archive.org/web/20220225131746/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.

4/3/22  From 1st March Rules have been relaxed and masks are now required indoors only.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220304082256/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

Attention! The number of persons vaccinated against COVID-19 is not counted if they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Museums and art galleries  They function in a strict sanitary regime. There is a limit of people - 1 person. on 15 m2.    Cinemas  They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    It is not allowed to eat or drink in the cinemas.    Theaters, operas, philharmonics  Outdoor:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners.    In rooms:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners. Ensuring that no more than 1 person per 15 m2 of the area is present in the room at the same time. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    Houses and centers of culture  Conducting activities by cultural centers and centers as well as community centers is allowed in the open air and indoors, provided that the participation does not exceed 30%. participants. Ensure that participants follow the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Concerts and circus performances  Events may take place under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,    keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience and ensure that no more than 1 person per 15 square meters is present in the room at the same time,    ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Concerts and circus performances may be organized outdoors under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,    keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience,    ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Outdoor amusement parks  Amusement parks may operate at up to 30%. occupancy.    Libraries  Possibility to make collections available, provided that no more than 1 person per 15 mÂ² is present in the library, with the exception of librarians. Before entering the library, information about the limit of people should be posted.    Conducting activities by public and scientific libraries consisting in the organization of meetings and events is allowed indoors, provided that:    while maintaining a distance of 1.5 m between participants;    that participants comply with the obligation to cover their mouth and nose.    Night clubs, discos and other places available for dancing  Nightclubs, discos and other places to dance have closed.    Fairs, exhibitions, congresses, conferences  Trade fairs, congresses and conferences can be organized within the limit of 1 person per 15 m2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128093751/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/kultura-i-rozrywka

Assembly  All types of meetings may be attended by up to 100 people. Participants are required to keep 1.5 m away from other people. In addition, the distance between assemblies must not be less than 100 m.    Meetings  Up to 100 people can participate in outdoor events and meetings, either in the premises or in a dedicated social area . There is a distance between the tables (every second table can be occupied, the distance between the tables must be at least 1.5 m - unless there is a partition at least 1 m high between them, counting from the surface of the table) .    Weddings, communions, consolations and other celebrations  You can organize special events outside and inside (e.g. in a restaurant). There is a limit of people - max. 100. Such events could take place in strict sanitary regime. There is a distance between the tables (every second table can be occupied, the distance between the tables must be at least 1.5 m - unless there is a partition at least 1 m high between them, counting from the surface of the table) .    go to end view    https://web.archive.org/web/20220204133826/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zgromadzenia-i-imprezy

Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206100800/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

25/2/22  There are no stay at home requirements.  Mask wearing in public and social distancing are required.    Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians. Rules for travelers coming to Poland from European Union Member States, from the Schengen area and others  If you are traveling with:    European Union Member States,  Switzerland  Iceland,  Norway  Liechtenstein,  Principality of Andorra,  Principalities of Monaco,  The Republic of San Marino,  Vatican City State  you are subject to a 7-day quarantine.     You are not quarantined if:    you are vaccinated with the full vaccination course:  a vaccine that is authorized in the European Union or is included in the list of vaccine equivalents authorized for marketing in the territory of the Republic of Poland, kept by the National Institute of Public Health PZH - National Research Institute,  14 days have elapsed since the administration of the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the administration of the last dose),  vaccination is certified by the EU digital COVID certificate or other document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination.  You have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (you are the so-called healer):  not later than 6 months before the day of crossing the PR border,  you have a document that confirms the presence of the disease, issued in Polish or English, including the EU COVID Certificate,  You will present a negative COVID-19 test result:  certified by the EU digital COVID certificate or other document in Polish or English,  the test must be performed no earlier than 48 hours before crossing the border,  You are 12 or under and traveling with adults who are vaccinated against COVID-19 or tested negative for COVID-19.  You are subject to other exemptions listed in Â§ 3 of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of May 6, 2021 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with the occurrence of an epidemic.  If you have been quarantined, you can perform a test up to 48 hours after crossing the border, the negative result of which will release you from quarantine.    Also check who is exempt from the obligation to quarantine after crossing the state border.    What test can I do?    Test type: RT-PCR and antigen test.  Tests are not publicly funded.  Are you a foreigner?    Check the border crossing rules for foreigners.    Traveler Location Card  A person who crosses the state border of the Republic of Poland by plane fills in the Traveler Location Card in an electronic form before check-in , and if this is not possible - a paper-based travel location card provided by the cabin crew.    The data administrator is the state poviat sanitary inspector competent for the place of residence or stay of the traveler.    EU COVID Certificate  The EU COVID Certificate is issued by the Ministry of Health. A vaccination certificate is issued:    in electronic form,  in paper form;  by providers of immunization against COVID-19,  by a primary care physician or primary care nurse.  Detailed information on the EU COVID Certificate .    Important! This communication is provided for information purposes only and cannot be used as a basis for adjudicating on a case-by-case basis. The verification on the basis of the document presented for inspection and the final decision on quarantine or grounds for exemption from such a requirement will be taken by a Border Guard officer who performs border control.    In disputed / doubtful / random matters regarding sanitary restrictions / quarantine / vaccinations - including the rules for exemptions, shortening its duration - the only competent authority is the State (Border) Sanitary Inspector at the local level, or a higher level authority, i.e. the Minister responsible for Health (Chief Sanitary Inspector).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220221121222/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-ze-strefy-schengen

25/2/22  For those arriving from outside the Schengen area that are unvaccinated quarantine is required. For all vaccinated travellers a PCR test is required for entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214181845/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

25/2/22  For those arriving from outside the Schengen area that are unvaccinated quarantine is required. For all vaccinated travellers a PCR test is required for entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214181845/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

4/3/22  Rules for travelers coming to Poland from outside the European Union and from outside the Schengen area  Mandatory COVID-19 tests  People traveling from outside the European Union, from outside the Schengen area, must show a negative COVID-19 test result. You must complete the test regardless of the way in which you travel (collective, individual or on foot). Failure to test will require quarantine.    The obligation to perform the test also applies to vaccinated people or convalescents!    The test result must not be more than 24 hours prior to arrival.  The test can be performed at some airports in Poland - before border clearance or 3 hours after arrival (counting from border clearance).  quarantine   Attention! Persons crossing the Polish-Ukrainian border due to an armed conflict in Ukraine are not currently subject to the obligation to quarantine entry.    You are not quarantined if your antigen or PCR test is negative  and you meet one of the following conditions :    you are vaccinated with the full vaccination course:  a vaccine that is authorized in the European Union or is included in the list of vaccine equivalents authorized for marketing in the territory of the Republic of Poland, kept by the National Institute of Public Health PZH - National Research Institute,  14 days have elapsed since the administration of the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the administration of the last dose),  vaccination is certified by the EU COVID Certificate or another document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination.  You have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (you are the so-called healer):  not later than 6 months before the day of crossing the PR border,  you have a document that confirms the presence of the disease, issued in Polish or English, including the EU COVID Certificate .  You are subject to other exemptions listed in Â§ 3 of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of May 6, 2021 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with the occurrence of an epidemic.  Who is exempt from showing COVID-19 test results when arriving from outside the Schengen area?       Important! If you do not submit a negative test result, you must go into quarantine for  7 days .      What test can I do?    before crossing the border: RT-PCR or antigenic.  Tests are not publicly funded.    Important!     Persons who, after arriving from outside the Schengen area, the EU, stay in the territory of the Republic of Poland for no longer than 24 hours and have a flight ticket confirming departure from the territory of the Republic of Poland within 24 hours, may be exempt from the obligation to undergo quarantine, provided that:    show a negative result of the SARS-CoV-2 test (antigenic, PCR) performed within 24 hours before arrival to the Republic of Poland,  perform such a test before the border check (applies only to airports where it is possible),  perform the test at the airport after the border check within 3 hours.  Traveler Location Card  Each person who crosses the state border of the Republic of Poland by plane fills in the Traveler Location Card in an electronic form before check-in . If this is not possible, fill it in on a paper form provided by the cabin crew.    The data administrator is the state poviat sanitary inspector (sanepid) competent for the place of residence or stay of the traveler.    EU COVID Certificate  The EU COVID Certificate is issued by the Ministry of Health. A vaccination certificate is issued:    in electronic form,  in paper form;  by providers of immunization against COVID-19,  by a primary care physician or primary care nurse.  Detailed information on the  EU COVID Certificate .    Also check the  Border Guard website for information on quarantine after crossing the border.    Important! This communication is provided for information purposes only and cannot be used as a basis for adjudicating on a case-by-case basis. The verification on the basis of the document presented for inspection and the final decision on quarantine or grounds for exemption from such a requirement will be taken by a Border Guard officer who performs border control.    In disputed / doubtful / random matters regarding sanitary restrictions / quarantine / vaccinations - including the rules for exemptions, shortening its duration - the only competent authority is the State (Border) Sanitary Inspector at the local level, or a higher level authority, i.e. the Minister responsible for Health (Chief Sanitary Inspector).    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206124352/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/jak-zrobic-test-na-koronawirusa-w-aptece

Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .      https://web.archive.org/web/20220204154012/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

11/3/22  Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .      https://web.archive.org/web/20220204154012/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

Limited contact tracing in place.    I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206100800/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

25/2/22  No change in policy    Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity. Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206100800/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     https://web.archive.org/web/20220127030346/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     https://web.archive.org/web/20220127030346/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

25/2/22    We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     https://web.archive.org/web/20220127030346/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

Are vaccinations voluntary?  Vaccination is voluntary, except for healthcare professionals, pharmacists, medical students and healthcare professionals who must be fully vaccinated by March 1, 2022. We encourage other people to vaccinate against COVID-19. The more people get vaccinated, the more effective protection against the coronavirus will be.     https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/pytania-i-odpowiedzi
