Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the  evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the  institution.    4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as  in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical  presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of  the space.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the  evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the  institution.    4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as  in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical  presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of  the space.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

11.	The learning and teaching process in pre-school and daycare institutions shall take place according to the recommendations for pre-school institutions of NIPHK dated 20.01.2022.      12.	The learning and teaching process in all pre-university education institutions of all levels, as well as in daycare centres shall take place in accordance with the MEST Guidelines for the organization of the educational process in the conditions of the Covid-19 pandemic. The task forces of the educational institutions decide on the application of scenarios for the organization of the teaching process, depending on the situation in the institution and in the classrooms.    13.	The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of the space.     14.	Students must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2 in order to be allowed registration to the dormitory.    15.	Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the institution.    16.	Staff in all public and private institutions of all levels of education, including preschool and daycare institutions, must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the institution building.     17.	The highest administrative officer, or equivalent position, of each institution according to points 14, 15 and 16, is obliged by decision to appoint one or more responsible persons who will control the possession of any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315002518/https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/https:/msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

Unless otherwise specified in this Decision, indoor gatherings of up to 50% of capacities (workshops, meetings, seminars, trainings or other gatherings) are allowed. Except those under the age of 12, participants are obliged to possess any of the evidence mentioned in points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter these premises, and the organizer is obliged to provide a physical distance of one (1) meter between persons and check the relevant evidence, such as:      19.1	Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine against COVID-19;  19.2	Persons with medical evidence issued by the specialist doctor of the respective field verifying that they have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination must present the negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, which should not be older than 48 hours;  19.3	Single dose vaccination certificate, not older than one (1) month.  19.4	Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days).    20.	Meetings of the Assembly and Government are allowed regardless of the number of persons, respecting the wearing of masks and maintaining the physical distance of 1 (one) meter between persons.      21.	The Emergency Operational Centre of the Ministry of Health may issue a special permit, exceeding 50% of capacities, for events of special importance in the function of public interest.    22.	Outdoor gatherings and cultural events are allowed. The organizer is obliged to ensure the observation of measures, including the maintenance of a physical distance of 1 meter between persons and the presentation of evidence recorded in points 19.1 to 19.4, except participants under the age of 12, as well as the wearing of masks.    23.	Religious ceremonies and rites are allowed to carry out their activity up to 50% of the utilizing capacity, provided that they possess any of the evidence according to points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter the indoor spaces, in accordance with the relevant instruction, except participants under the age of 12.    https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

Every person who enters the Republic of Kosovo shall possess one of the following  evidence:  2.1 Certificate of full vaccination with two doses or a single-dose of Janssen  (J&J) vaccine not exceeding more than 12 months after receiving the last  dose;  2.2 Certificate of vaccination with a single dose accompanied with a negative  RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  2.3 Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90  days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days);  2.4 Evidence that the person has received the third / booster dose;  2.5 Evidence of negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours.    Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo who do not have two doses of vaccine are  obliged to respect home quarantine for a period of seven (7) days from the  entry into the territory of the Republic of Kosovo;     https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Entry and Exit Requirements  Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? Varies (see below)  As of March 1, 2022, every person who enters Kosovo must produce one of the following:  Full vaccination certificate with two (2) doses (or a single-dose of Janssen vaccine) not exceeding more than 12 months after receiving the last dose;  Vaccination certificate with a single dose, together with a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days);  Evidence that the person has received the third / booster dose;  Evidence of negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  This requirement does not apply to children under the age of 12. Children from 12 to 16 years of age must have a negative RT-PCR test not older than 48 hours.    Airlines, transit points, and destination countries impose a patchwork of different testing requirements and airlines may refuse boarding for some passengers (including U.S. citizens and Kosovo residents). Airlines have the sole authority to decide who they allow to board their aircraft. Generally, pre-travel testing is recommended.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  The Pristina International Airport is open to travelers.  Check with the airlines, airports, and the U.S. Embassies located in your countries of transit to verify entry/exit requirements and be aware that they change frequently.    Quarantine Information  Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? Yes â self quarantine.  Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo, as well as persons with temporary or permanent resident permits, who enter the Republic of Kosovo and do not possess the evidence required above and seek to enter the country are obliged to respect home quarantine for a period of seven (7) days from the entry into the territory of the Republic of Kosovo.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kosovo? Yes  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina and major towns in Kosovo.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.  Are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Turn-around time for results from the private clinics vary from several hours to 24 hours and are available via email and hard copy. Results from UCCK are reportedly available within 24 hours, but it is best to check with them due to expected higher demand.  If you are in Kosovo and have COVID-19 related questions, are symptomatic, or need information regarding testing, please call toll free 038 200 80 800, or dial 194.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse or recommend any particular healthcare provider, but below is a list of clinics and hospitals who are providing tests. Please contact them directly for details on location, tests offered, and pricing:  Medical and Laboratory Services SHPK, +383 48 111 000 or +383 38 600 188  Prolab, +383 49 789 410  Olive Lab, +383 38 720 055, +383 49 520 056  UBT â Laboratory I Microbiology e Clinic, + 383 46 500 777, +383 46 500 888  Avicena, +383 49 825 555  UCCK â University Clinical Center Kosovo (public hospital), +381 38 500 600    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211185746/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/  Enter new data here for Kosovo. Staff in all public and private institutions of all levels of education, including  preschool and daycare institutions, must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point  4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the institution building.     Students must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2 in order to be  allowed registration to the dormitory    The highest administrative officer, or equivalent position, of public, private institutions,  as well as other entities, is obliged to appoint one or more responsible persons who will  control the possession of any of the evidence mentioned in points 4.1 to 4.2.     All employees of public institutions, central and local public enterprises, private  businesses, organizations, as well as other entities, must possess one of the following  evidence, in order to be allowed to enter the work premises:    4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;

Russian government website can't be accessed due to military operation in Ukraine, but following measures have been put in place until april:    From October 25, 2021 to April 1, 2022, metropolitan enterprises must transfer to remote work:  at least 30 percent of the total number of employees;  all workers over 60 years of age and suffering from chronic diseases. Russian government website can't be accessed due to military operation in Ukraine, but following measures have been put in place until april:    People above 60 in Moscow must stay at home or in their country house. They can go out only in these cases: when they need to go to the store, walk their pets, take out the trash, go to work, to the clinic or hospital, take a walk or play sports in the fresh air. On 18 March 2020 the Russian government introduced restrictions on entry into the whole country for almost all foreign citizens. On 30 March 2020, temporary restrictions on entry and exit via Russiaâs land borders were enforced. The duration of these remains unspecified.    These restrictions were eased on 16 April 2021 for nationals and permanent residents of certain countries including the UK. They may now travel to Russia by air via authorised 3rd countries. The full list is subject to change and currently includes Albania; Andorra; Argentina; Armenia; Austria; Azerbaijan; Bahamas; Bahrain; Bangladesh; Belgium; Brazil; Bulgaria; China; Columbia; Costa Rica; Croatia; Cuba; Cyprus; Czech Republic; Denmark; Djibouti; Dominican Republic; Egypt; Ethiopia; Finland; France; Germany; Greece; Hungary; Iceland; India; Iran; Iraq; Italy; Japan; Jordan; Kazakhstan; Kenya; Kuwait; Kyrgyzstan; Lebanon; Lichtenstein; Luxemburg; Maldives; Malta; Mauritius; Mexico; Moldova; Mongolia; Morocco; Netherlands; New Zealand; North Macedonia; Norway; Oman; Peru; Portugal; Qatar; Republic of Ireland; Republic of Korea; Republic of Seychelles; Saudi Arabia; Serbia; Singapore; Slovakia; Slovenia; Spain, Sri-Lanka; Sweden; Switzerland; Syria; Tajikistan; Thailand; Tunisia; Turkey; United Arab Emirates; United Kingdom.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307230828/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/entry-requirements

The Authorities of the Republic of San Marino issued Decree-Law no. 3 of 14 January 2022 - Strengthening of provisions to avoid the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The provisions of the aforementioned Decree-Law, ratified by Decree-Law no. 6 of 21 January 2022, unless otherwise provided for, shall apply until the end of the health emergency, which is currently extended until 30 April 2022.         Entry into the Republic of San Marino, for those coming from countries other than Italy and the Vatican City, or who have stayed outside these two countries in the previous 14 days, is permitted on presentation of the following documents:         A certificate of vaccination against SARS-CoV-2* or a certificate of recovery from SARS-CoV-2 within the previous six months. This certificate may be in paper or digital form;  Or    A negative coronavirus test certificate following a molecular or antigenic swab taken no later than 48 hours before entry and in any case in accordance with the health protocols in force in the Republic of San Marino. Any molecular swab taken within 48 hours prior to entry into the territory of the Italian Republic is considered valid for those who do not fall within the cases referred to in letter a) above.        Children under ten years of age are exempt from submitting the certificates referred to in letters a) and b).    https://web.archive.org/web/2021*/https://www.esteri.sm/pub2/EsteriSM/en/Covid/Covid.html

Starting December 20, 2020 the Government of Serbia is reporting that foreigners seeking to enter Serbia will need to provide a negative PCR test, not older than 48 hours. These measures are reported to not apply to several categories of travelers, including:  Foreign citizens in transit, with 12 hours allowed between entry to and exit from Serbia.  Minors up to 12 years of age, provided the parent, custodian or any other person accompanying the minor has a negative PCR test, if it is needed.  Crew and cabin crew of aircraft whose final destination is Serbia.  Crew, personnel, and passengers in transit through Serbiaâs international airports.  Accredited staff of foreign diplomatic and consular missions, as well as offices of international organizations. Also included are family members with diplomatic status in Serbia. Foreign citizens who have been granted temporary residence or permanent residence in Serbia.  As of July 24, 2021 the Government of Serbia is reporting that foreign citizens may enter Serbia without a negative COVID-19 test if they possess proof of recovery from COVID-19 at least 14 days prior to their entry and no more than 6 months prior to their entry.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307214010/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

No change.    A supplementary budget with new support measures was adopted in April 2021. New measures include: (i) wage subsidies, including payment of Â½ of minimum wages for all entrepreneurs and employees in SMEs and large companies for three months (RSD 69.8 billion); (ii) additional payments for employees in travel, hospitality, and art (RSD 4.4 billion); (iii) universal cash transfer of EUR 60 to each citizen over 18 years old, paid in two installments of EUR 30 eachâin May and November (RSD 43.2 billion);(iv) a one-off payment of EUR 50 to all pensioners (RSD 10 billion);(v)a one-off financial assistance of EUR 60 to all the unemployed, paid in June (RSD 4.3 billion); and (vi) support for the transport sector and for city hotels (RSD 3.9bn); and a one-off payment of EUR 25 to all vaccinated citizens (RSD 9 billion). The total estimated cost amounts to 2.5 percent of GDP. It also includes additional healthcare spending and increased public investment (2 percent of GDP), mostly in infrastructure, environmental protection, and defense. The existing scheme for state guaranteed bank loans to SMEs has been expanded by EUR 500 million (1 percent of GDP) and a new EUR 500 million scheme for vulnerable companies has been established.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307220224/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

During their stay in public places indoors, citizens are obliged to wear protective masks and maintain a distance of at least two meters between two persons who do not reside in the same household, in order to prevent the spread of the infectious disease COVID-19.    In public places in the open, if it is not possible to maintain a distance of at least two meters between two people (in front of shops, pharmacies, bus and other stops, etc.), wearing protective masks is mandatory. It is obligatory to wear protective masks in public road and rail transport of passengers. Parents of minor children or children with special needs, ie their guardians, are obliged to ensure that children older than four years wear a protective mask in the cases referred to in para. 1â3. of this article.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307222130/https://www.propisi.net/uredbu-o-merama-za-sprecavanje-i-suzbijanje-zarazne-bolesti-covid-19/

Vaccination is free for general publicity. Currently, COVID-19 vaccines are available free of charge to all citizens who wish to be vaccinated. Vaccines used: Pfizer-BioNTech, AstraZeneca, Sputnik V, and Sinopharm. No vaccine mandates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307214010/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

Vaccines used: Pfizer-BioNTech, AstraZeneca, Sputnik V, and Sinopharm. No vaccine mandates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220307214010/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

From 5 February, employers are no longer obliged to prevent those who are unvaccinated from entering workplaces; employers are still recommended to provide voluntary testing for employees.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220205135335/https://korona.gov.sk/opatrenia-pre-vstup-zamestnancov-na-pracovisko-zamestnavatela/

All mass event attendees must be fully vaccinated; those who are unvaccinated must have proof of full COVID-19 recovery within the past 90 days. Mass events can now go ahead under strict restrictions. Events have been categorised into low, medium and high risk:  - Low risk: capacity of 100 or 50% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks, food and drinks are prohibited, sitting is mandatory, and event takes place without singing, encouragement or other loud vocal expressions.  - Medium risk: capacity of 100 or 25% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks and here is a fixed sitting or standing arrangement.   - High risk: capacity of 20 people. Defined as events in a public catering operation or a non-low-risk mass event and a medium-risk mass event; this includes weddings, parties and other celebrations.   Funerals are exempt from these restrictions, as are meetings of public authorities, elections, and mass events necessary for the course of the following professional competitions in selected sports.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214110040/https://korona.gov.sk/obmedzenia-pre-hromadne-podujatia/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220124225901/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4988:informacia-k-novym-vyhlakam-uvz-sr-respiratory-hromadne-podujatia-prevadzky-otp-na-pracoviskach&catid=56:tlaove-spravy&Itemid=62

Gatherings of more than 6 are prohibited unless from the same household, or attending an officially organised mass event.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123195341/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/
Public transport is fully open, with masks required.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220220092344/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"All public transportation, including taxis and ride sharing services, requires the use of FFP2/K95/N95 face masks."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220225085704/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Country-wide curfew has now been lifted. People are told to stay at home if they feel unwell and not attend hospitals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123195341/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/
There is no restrictions on internal movement.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220220092344/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No apparent restrictions.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220225085704/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Everyone aged over 12 years and 2 months arriving from all countries by all means of transport must register in advance of travel by completing the âeHranicaâ form on the Slovak governmentâs website. Fully vaccinated and recently recovered travellers do not need to quarantine but must carry proof of vaccination or recovery. Unvaccinated travellers must either self-quarantine for 5 days and then quarantine ends as long as they remain asymptomatic; OR travellers may take a PCR test at any time after entry and self-isolation will end upon receipt of the negative results.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220092344/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220205134008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/entry-requirements

No change in policy. FP2-standard face masks are required at all indoor venues and areas, at outdoor mass events, and when outdoors and less than 2m from people outside of your household.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220221112332/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4988%3Ainformacia-k-novym-vyhlakam-uvz-sr-respiratory-hromadne-podujatia-prevadzky-otp-na-pracoviskach&catid=56%3Atlaove-spravy&Itemid=62

Registration for COVID-19 vaccination is open to anyone from the age of 12. Certain hospitals are offering vaccinations without registration. The national vaccination programme is currently using the Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, and Janssen (Johnson and Johnson) vaccines.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220221114554/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220221114552/https://www.mic.iom.sk/en/news/637-covid-19-measures.html

Vaccination available to people 12+.   Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20220221114554/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220221114552/https://www.mic.iom.sk/en/news/637-covid-19-measures.html

Those over 60, regardless of vaccination status, are advised to:  - stay away from the sick and limit all close contact, avoiding crowds as much as possible.   - avoid traveling on public transport.  - only go out when necessary, such as buying groceries.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220123215417/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Osoby_s_vyssim_rizikom_ochorenia_COVID-19.pdf

https://archive.vn/CEfdD  Ending of most Covid restrictions -  no more testing (rapid antigen or PCR) in schools)   face masks still required in school  Advise that symptomatic persons should stay home

Schools are fully open. Self-testing is no longer required, through wearing face masks is still mandatory. Students who are ill are told to stay home.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309165115/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309165201/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170133/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Workers in healthcare and social care institutions and in prisons are required to comply by the "RVT - recovered, vaccinated, or tested" rule to enter workplaces. This has been relaxed, with previously more places of work having to abide by this rule.  - Recovery must be proved via a positive PCR result in the last 180 days  - An individual is considered vaccinated from the day of their vaccination, and onwards.  - Tests can either be in the form of a rapid antigen test conducted in the last 48 hours or a PCR test conducted in the last 72 hours.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170133/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1643.0-1647.108  The organisation of public cultural events in open public spaces is not permitted, but it is permitted in enclosed public spaces with fixed seating, whereby every other seat must be left vacant, the use of face masks is mandatory, and all participants must comply with the recovered/vaccinated/tested rule.    Public cultural events may only be held on condition that the performers and people involved in the organisation of the event that have direct contact with visitors meet the requirements of the recovered/vaccinated/tested rule. This condition does not apply to persons under the age of 12. The public cultural event can be attended by a maximum of 750 visitors.

Following easing of almost all restrictions on the 22nd of February, there is no longer any restrictions on public events taking place, though masks are recommended at outdoor events where 1.5m social distancing is not possible.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170902/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/9624-slovenia-ends-almost-all-covid-restrictions-except-masks

There is no longer a cap on the number of people allowed to gather, either in public or private  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170902/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/9624-slovenia-ends-almost-all-covid-restrictions-except-masks

Public transport is running as usual. The use of masks is mandatory for drivers and passengers over 6 years of age. Cable-cars on ski slopes are also running, with windows opening an a 1.5m distance rule observed whilst queuing and using the cable-cars.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170133/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

As of 19 February 2022, a person who has been in close contact with a person who tested positive in a coronavirus test will no longer have to quarantine at home. People who are ill are recommended to stay home.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309165115/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

There are no restrictions on internal movement within Slovenia.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170133/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

All travellers arriving in Slovenia will no longer be required to present proof of vaccination or a negative COVID-19 test. All travellers arriving in Slovenia must continue to complete the Digital Passenger Locator Form 24 hours before arrival, if entering via an airport or a ferry terminal. The form is not required if entering overland at a border crossing.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/entry-requirements & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171842/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/border-crossing/

Tests are no longer generally available for free. Free testing with a rapid antigen test and a rapid antigen test for self-testing has been abolished and the government budget will only pay for testing with a rapid antigen test for activities where this is still required, such as entering health or social care institutions, and prisons. Due to high demand, PCR tests are limited to those who have had a negative rapid test result and are advised by their doctor to get a PCR test due to showing symptoms or coming into contact with someone with a positive result.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309165115/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Free testing with a rapid antigen test and a rapid antigen test for self-testing has been abolished and the government budget will only pay for testing with a rapid antigen test for activities where this is still required, such as entering health or social care institutions, and prisons. Due to high demand, PCR tests are limited to those who have had a negative rapid test result and are advised by their doctor to get a PCR test due to showing symptoms or coming into contact with someone with a positive result.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309165115/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

People are encouraged via the government website to download the #OstaniZdrav mobile application, which is intended to record contact between people who have installed the application on their mobile phones. After contact, the application displays a low or high risk of COVID-19 transmission, with application status updated every 4 hours. This has been designed to encourage citizens to behave more responsibly.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309180516/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/the-ostanizdrav-mobile-application/

Surgical mask II or IIR or a FFP2 or a FFP3 mask are mandatory in all closed public spaces and on public transport. Protective masks are recommended in open public spaces or outside if a distance of at least 1.5 metres is not possible to maintain.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170133/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Vaccines are available for those age 12 and older. AstraZeneca, Moderna, and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines are all available. Vaccination is free of charge and is provided to all those who have permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia, regardless of whether they are insured.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309181259/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/cepljenje-proti-covid-19/

No specific protections are in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170133/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

9th Feb 2022, Sweden scrapped almost all of its few pandemic restrictions on Wednesday and stopped most testing for COVID-19, even as the pressure on the healthcare systems remained high and some scientists begged for more patience in fighting the disease.    Advice and recommendations  - Get vaccinated if you can  The Swedish Public Health Agency recommends that everyone aged 12 and older be vaccinated against covid-19. It reduces the risk of serious illness and death.    - Stay home if you have symptoms  Anyone with symptoms of Covid-19 should stay at home and  avoid close contacts with others if you are ill with symptoms of Covid-19.    - Special advice to those not vaccinated  Not being vaccinated increases the risk of serious illness from Covid-19. To avoid becoming infected, people who are unvaccinated should be extra careful and avoid crowded indoor environments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115741/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210135400/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/sweden-declare-pandemic-over-despite-warnings-scientists-2022-02-09/

A ban on entry to Sweden is in effect for non-essential travel from most countries outside the EU/EEA. The ban does not apply to Swedish citizens, citizens of another EU/EEA country or citizens from a number of exempt countries. Swedish citizens and foreign nationals who are registered in Sweden are always entitled to travel into Sweden.    Read more under International travel, where you will find information about which countries are exempt from the entry ban and what is needed in order to be granted an exemption from the entry ban.     Foreign nationals travelling to Sweden from countries outside EU/EEA must be exempted from the travel ban and show evidence of a negative test of Covid-19, from within the past 72 hours.    There is from 9 February 2022 no longer an entry ban from an EU/EEA country, but from the rest of the world the entry ban is in effect till 31 March 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220222101403/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

You will need to complete the online form (Form for Entry to Turkey), a maximum of 72 hours before travelling, to enter Turkey if aged 6 and over. This is not necessary for transit passengers. All arrivals into Turkey will be subject to a medical evaluation for symptoms of coronavirus, including temperature checks. Arrivals may be subject to random PCR testing on arrival. If youâre fully vaccinated, you can enter Turkey without needing to test or quarantine. At least 14 days must have passed since your second dose of the vaccine and the vaccine must be approved by the Turkish Ministry of Health or World Health Organization. You must present proof that you have been fully vaccinated to enter Turkey. If youâre not fully vaccinated, youâll need to show proof of a negative PCR test (taken no more than 72 hours before entry), rapid antigen test (taken no more than 48 hours before entry), or proof of a recent recovery from COVID-19 within the last six months, when entering Turkey.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220221211338/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkey/entry-requirements
